description:
Very authentic food with reasonable prices and great ambiance!  We came for lunch and had the Ghormeh Sabzi (served elegantly with lamb on the bone) along with the combination platter (Dolma, kashk bodemjan, cucumbers, tomatoes, fresh herbs, feta, cheese, and greek olives) that also happened to feature some kookoo sabzi.  

As I am familiar with the flavors and dishes, they were all delicious and authentic! However, if you are exposing someone to Persian/Iranian food for the first time, you may want to pick the combination platter and a different main dish such as Khoresh Gheymeh Bodemjah to mix up the palate of flavors.  To be fair, the Gheymeh Bodemjah was recommended by our waitress, but I was stubborn and wanted my guest to try the Khoresh Ghormeh Sabzi since I had talked it up so much. :)  
[As a side note, the kebabs around all looked and smelled good as well, but I would make sure to make sure that all newcomers to the cuisine definitely try a khoresh at least once!]

For dessert, we had the Makhlut (faloodeh and bastani combination), which was amazing.  Even if I wasn't hungry, I would come here any day just to eat the dessert alone with how perfect it was. 

Everything was delicious, though the only improvement would be for an option or so that would allow even more breadth of Persian/Iranian cuisine's flavors to try in one sitting for those who have never had Persian food would be nice.  However, I know this is likely a rather unrealistic request and just a hopeful one.  

I would absolutely recommend visiting!  The flavors and options are far more authentic than any Persian restaurant I know of that is still running in the San Francisco - San Jose region as of this review.
author: John B.

description:
If you are looking for authentic food and like to try different foods , this is the place to go !!
Great ambiance with good service! 
Whenever we crave Persian food we go to Alborz and our friends have always enjoyed their food as well. 
Highly recommend it !!
author: Ben K.

description:
I've never had Persian cuisine before, so I decided to give it a try, being the adventurous eater that I am. When I ordered the chicken kabob, I first got the onion pieces and butter. I did not know what Persian cuisine was and I thought that was the appetizer and I ate a little of it.. so embarrassing for me but now I think it was funny! I highly recommend the kabob. The chicken was grilled just right so it was juicy and tender. The portion was quite generous. When the chicken is consumed with the butter and onions, it was perfection! 

The restaurant has a nice window layout that allows you to enjoy the city views of Civic Center, featuring large windows that let natural light in. There are several tables that are directly next to the windows. I appreciated the cultural artifacts here are there, which seemed limited to Persian pottery. Brown and yellow is an attractive color scheme. I would also point people towards the Persian tea, which tastes like a strong black tea with rose notes. Free refills on the Persian tea!
author: Louis Suo L.

description: Have been looking for Persian in the city since I moved here! I absolutely loved it here! The chicken koobideh and hummus is what I got and shared with my boyfriend! Plenty of food for the both of us. Really great service and atmosphere I highly recommend this place!!
author: Anna A.

description:
Absolutely great,
The restaurant is at the corner of a one of the crowded streets in San Francisco area . The main salon does have a view of the street.
The lady who got our order( azadeh ) was attentive, polite, and responsive.
The kashkeh Bademjoon was freshly made, and designed by fried mint and chopped-fried onions).
We ordered 3 combo dishes-which was included joojeh , koobideh , and Barg.
The Barg was so tender ,  juicy, and medium -rare.the cook used  melted butter on the top of the kabobs to juice it more.koobideh was completely fresh and warm., I believe they have used lamb meat.The only thing that was a little bit off , the joojeh ( they used breast not the thigh), so it was a little bit dry.
Recommended to SF residents and tourists
author: Atosa T.

description:
Alborz Persian Cuisine

I went with a party of four on June 5,2017. My partner is Iranian and hasn't had Persian food since his arrival in San Francisco. Luckily, my best friend's mom suggested this place and wanted to experience Iranian cuisine. 

The order:
Alborz plate for Two, 40$ 
Koobideh 16$
Baghali Polo With Lamb Shank 14$
Appetizer Combo plate 15$ 

Makhlut 8.50$ x2
Baklava 6$

For my first time trying out Iranian cuisine, I've gotta say that I licked my plate absolutely clean. I liked the chicken koobideh in the Alborz plate for two because it was not only topped with saffron but the chicken was crispy and delicious on the inside. My partner really fancied the Barg, and my best friend liked the koobideh. Her mother loved her lamb shank and all around we really enjoyed our food. 

Service:
Our waiter was very busy thus we understood that he was handling 5-6 parties at the same time thus the service was a bit slow. He was friendly and spoke Farsi which was great! It's a good thing that my party had long discussions and didn't worry too much about our hunger. Would recommend to a friend.
author: Liza H.

description: I give this place 4 stars. The food is fantastic!!! And the portions are huge. The only thing that is wrong here is the service!! Somewhat unfriendly and only one waiter working through the whole place. Otherwise, everything else was great! Will come again for the food quality and hopefully better experience.
author: K H.

description:
The food was okay. However on the menu they said they charge  gratuity for six and more people.
We were party of 5 and the waiter charged us gratuity. Also they have to take care of the bugs.
author: Zarin M.

description: OMG bad service with bad not cooked food and when we asked to change the sweet rice with orange peels he said it's our problem  whyyyy !!!!!!plus when we ordered from the menu he didn't tell us that's he was going to add extra $3.50 on each plate beside he was very rude and un respectful person never will go back to this restaurant.
author: Israa H.

description: Food is authentic and delicious. Customer service is excellent. Asked for a to go box and the server boxed and wrapped the box in Saran Wrap. I had a 3 hour drive and ate it afterwards and it was still delicious!would recommend this place
author: Justin V.

description: Excellent Persian food friendly service and highly recommend! As a Persian I have a very discriminating palate when it comes to my homeland's food. Alborz never disappoints and is always delicious and fresh ingredients are used. The chicken joojeh is rich with lemon zest and marinated in saffron. The beef koobideh is enriched with bold flavor and tender. The baglavah must be had with Persian tea at the end. The portions are also quite large and perfect for sharing.
author: Tina A.

description: Delicious!! We wandered in here because it was 1 block from our hotel. So glad we did! Everything was delicious from the humus to the filet mignon kebabs. Meat falling off the bone. Sauces and rice dripping in fresh spices. Wonderful wines. Waiter was funny and kind to our kids.. Lovely dinner out!
author: Mary H.

description:
This place is pretty decent. The waitress was pretty solid and the food was good. The decor is fine, location is fine although parking is difficult if you have a car--if possible I would recommend walking to the restaurant. 

Currently there is construction near the front of the restaurant so it's not visible from the street, but do be sure to try it.
author: Armand A.

description: If you guys want to experience Persian cuisine than this is the place to go. Their food was delicious. Price is reasonable. Very pleasant people who work there. And their decor was very Persian, very Middle Eastern.
author: Tiffany E.

description:
Service was horrible, only 1 waitress while the owner just walked around and both were rude. Took over 2 hours to get our food and get out of there.

We just got home, and the 2 of us are feeling sick as dogs. Kubideh looked like it was submerged in olive oil, prior to being plated. Chicken didn't even seem like chicken. The Tadig wasn't crispy!? 

Will not go back and will never recommend. The 1 star is for the Dough.
author: Nick K.

description: Just stumbled on this place for lunch today. The chicken koobideh kebab was PHENOMENAL, so wa the beef kebab. Service was friendly, attentive and excellent. This meal hit the spot and we'll be back! :)
author: Ragini T.

description: Accidental review--Yelp please fix this from the App!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I will delete this asap
author: Koohyar H.

description: We entered the restaurant at 9:08pm this evening and were rudely told that they are closed when advertised as open until 10pm. Not "sorry we are closed" or "unfortunately our kitchen is closed" which would have been acceptable and not resulted in a poor review. Enough said!
author: Shadow S.

description: Friendly staff. Bread was very good. Chicken with bone was very tender and flavorful. Beef kabob was also tasty. Rice with berries was ok ,have had better. Ice cream was delicious.
author: Kristina M.

description: I give this place a one star because the server sucks!! I don't know why they have kept her for so long. She can't multi task and they won't hire another server. She had the busser doing all the work and her collecting the tips. Really sad because this place has a lot of potential. The food is great and the atmosphere is nice. But the host/server has got to go!
author: Sonia D.

description:
When it comes to Persian food, Alborz is to Anar (review: http://bit.ly/1L2PUHC) like Tuba (review: http://bit.ly/1B8dbEQ) is to A La Turca (review: http://bit.ly/1FafT7W) on the Turkish culinary palate, meaning I would be comparing an upscale white-tablecloth dinner with its down home-style counterpart. Do I favor one style over the other? It depends partially on my mood and the state of my wallet but mostly it depends on execution. I have higher expectations that the chef will hit it out of the ballpark in the white-tablecloth restaurant, even if it's in the middle of Teheran, but Alborz merely hits a grounder and barely gets a man on base. I convinced Jamie W. to come here after we shopped for moonshine at the BevMo across the street. We had a hankering after we had a taste of some in North Carolina. Don't judge me.

Anyway, we entered Alborz and were immediately seated at a table facing Van Ness between two rather loud parties. My guess is that they just want to show passers-by that they are a popular, convivial spot even though the rest of the restaurant was empty. Their specialty centers around their kabobs since there was an entire page devoted to all sorts of variations on them (photo: http://bit.ly/1Mrp09A), but first we focused on the appetizers as the server handed us some thin pita and raw onion with bits of parsley (photo: http://bit.ly/1L2PPDW). I assume that we were supposed to hand-roll some onion wraps since there were Land O' Lakes butter pats really to smear over the pita. While we did that, I decided we should try the $9 Tah Dig billed as "crispy rice topped with one kind stew". I wasn't sure what to do with that obscure description.

At the same time, I was familiar with the dish because an Iranian colleague of mine ordered it off-menu at Anar. That was delicious, but this version was not quite as good. It was a chili-like sauce with bits of beef and chickpeas over a flat of pan-fried rice (photo: http://bit.ly/1FU1QUB). It was more about the chili than the rice. Ordering our entrees was easy since it was all about the kabobs, but this is where it would have been helpful if there was a translation of some of the terms in the description so the layman would know if he is eating lamb or chicken. Jamie went for the $18.95 Joogeh Soltani which consisted of one skewer of chicken marinated with saffron (Joogeh) and minced onion and another skewer with ground lamb and chopped onions (Koobideh) (photo: http://bit.ly/1dymSRV). It was decent enough, but the chicken was not nearly as moist as either of us wanted.

The ground lamb, however, was fine. Mine was the more expensive $24.95 Soltani (or Sultan's meal) which consisted of the Koobideh as well as Barg, a more filet cut of lamb marinated with olive oil and grilled (photo: http://bit.ly/1MroGYt). It was certainly meatier than Jamie's order, but it frankly didn't appear to be worth the premium to order. We both had the same satisfying sides, a grilled tomato and basmati rice with streaks of saffron. By this time, we were well on our way on the meh train, but we decided to go for their premium price creation, the $8 Maklut, a combination of Persian ice cream with saffron and iced rice noodles frozen in rose water (photo: http://bit.ly/1I3hm1P). It was certainly not anything I've ever had before. I liked it enough, Jamie not so much. That pretty much summarizes our whole evening there.

FOOD - 3 stars...rather pricey Persian fare and only sporadically interesting
AMBIANCE - 3.5 stars...big place but i wish they wouldn't crowd us against the window
SERVICE - 3 stars...enthusiasm was on neutral here
TOTAL - 3 stars...I think Anar wins the battle of the classes on this one
author: Ed U.

description: My Favorite place in SF for Persian food! Their chicken kubideh is by far he best! And their staff was always so nice and attentive!
author: Christian C.

description: The tahdig and the stew was so delicious! I ordered the koobideh since I thought the portion might be small, but actually it was good enough, and I ended up taking Koobideh home! Very good experience overall
author: Nilou E.

description:
This place does not give complentary mint or feta cheese like all Persian restaurant's I've been to in SF or the South Bay. They only give onions with bread & cold butter. The Chicken serving is small on the entrees. Bathroom is in a far hallway, shared by other restaurants in the building. The Manager lady went out to give all other 5 table patrons their orders but sent the bus boy to give us our order. Interesting, but it was very obvious to us that we noticed it.
We will not return here, very poor service & they do not treat all their customers fairly.
author: Carol M.

description: HORRIBLE SERVICE. Literally was sitting at our table for over 30 min before we even got waters or bread (and it was 100 degrees outside and they didn't have AC INSIDE). Also, when we sat down they told us to hurry up and order because they were closing early since it was so hot outside. Ummmm what??? This was 7:30pm and their business is listed as closing at 10pm. Mind you this was a Saturday night. I am sitting at the table writing this review as we speak. As a Persian, I have dined at kabob restaurants over 100 times all over the Bay Area. Worst experience I've ever had. It's no wonder that this place is always empty when I walk by. Do not go.
author: Naseem K.

description:
I've actually stood outside this place many times, while waiting for the bus (47 & 49).  But I haven't had time to stop in.  

Food = good. 

Tabletop flatbread with sliced onions and parsley and butter to start. Delicious. 

Aash Reshteh = Persian noodle soup with fresh herbs and pinto beans, topped with fried onion and whey. Hearty soup,and full of flavor.  Cup for $4.95. (Lunch date had the bowl for $6.95.) 

Gheymeh Bodemjan = Lean tender beef with yellow split peas and eggplant braised in tomato broth with fried eggplant. Comes with rice. Delicious and definitely too much for me after the cup of soup. $14.95. 

Joogeh kabob = Skewer of chicken breast marinated in lime, saffron and olive oil. Comes with rice. Lunch date says it's one of her favorites. $13.95.

Prices = moderate but hearty portions. Lunch for two came out to $45.00 with leftovers. 

Service = friendly. Currently, they're a bit short staffed currently, so a bit slow, as they're trying to do everything from serving, bussing and checking on every single table. 

Seating = plenty.  This is a good place for groups.
author: Fannie S.

description: Terrible service, very unprofessional, uncooked food, cold. I had a very bad experience. I hope they realize that customer satisfaction matters and is the first and foremost important thing.
author: Majid D.

description: You can always count on them being open and no wait for a table. The quality of food is always great and they have a high health food score. Its a a pretty legit spot for Persian food.
author: Mark A.

description: My favorite Persian food in the Bay Area.  Always go for the jooojeh an any of the lamb shank dishes. Meat is always reliably tender and juices and the rice oh so fluffy and delish
author: Omar R.

description: Food was terrible, I had koobideh and it was raw. Service was bad also; just one person in charge of 6 tables. Do not recommend at all.
author: Bardia N.

description:
the food is ok but the service is dishonest. asked for fresh squeezed lemonade and caught the guy pouring in from a bottle, when i confronted him he said they make it in the morning. 
(im sure they make it and pour in a plastic freakin bottle.) If i wanted bottled lemonade, I wouldn't go out of my way to ask for fresh squeezed. 

won't go back to this place.

it's a big restaurant so you rarely have to wait for a table.
author: Dino K.

description:
This is a very nice Persian restaurant. It is fairly quiet. It has a nice and elegant ambiance.  It has good customer service.

During my visit, I tried the complementary pita bread, koobideh (ground beef), and Makhlut. The pita bread was warm and fresh and it was served with butter. The koobideh was very good. It was a kebab served with buttered rice and vegetables.  The meat was moist and tasty. The rice was moist, fluffy and delicious. The grilled vegetables were good.  The Makhlut desert was excellent. It consisted of two deserts, one was the Faloodeh and the other was the Persian ice cream.  It also came with some lemon juice. The desert was tasty and refreshing.

I enjoyed dinning at this restaurant.
author: Hiroshi K.

description:
Extremely BAD service, cheap owner only put a single waiter for the whole labour day Monday. Waited 10 mins without getting a greeting, ended up sitting myself without them sitting m since I was tired. Was told I can't order appetizer since they were busy (there were not, 5 tables max, but again single host working).

To the owner: one person for a holiday? U serious? You will lose a lot more than the $200 you saved by not having a second person wait tables that day.

This cheapness also concerns me as now I don't know what ingredients owner forces their chef to use.

Will NEVER EVER visit again, highly recommend against anyone going to such establishment where customers are treated like DMV.
author: Ali G.

description: The authenticity of the Persian food here delights me every time as I'm Persian and picky on quality of the ingredients. It's a quiet place in an odd location, so it's easy to miss. But I highly recommend it. Great stews, rice and kabobs. Great for take out, generous portions.
author: F S.

description:
Excellent food, excellent service. 
Food came out fast & wow! So delish! 
We ordered 3 koobideh with zeresch polo & lamb tongue. All dishes were on point! 
I also ordered a to go plate & another plate awaiting my nieces arrival and they were very accommodating.
author: chunx M.

description: Okay first of all...there was a HAIR in my food! The waiter seemed unamused. I asked for a new order, and he comes back to say there was no more, but then he said he could do it without the fried egg on top. I'm sure he just wanted to take the fried egg off in the back and bring me back the same dish. Whatever. Then I ordered a main entree that I was going to share with my bf and an appetizer. And we wait 10 mins...after 10 mins he brings a salad to apologize for the HAIR. Then we wait 30 mins, and see the other 2 tables that sat AFTER us be served. I asked the waiter if our food was almost ready, and he said "what food, u didn't order anything?" Ummm okay at this point I realize he's just being a little bitch, and asks if we still want to wait for it. Most annoying, frustrating, disrespectful experience ever. By the way the food looked basic, and I KNOW it was over priced bc I've been to plenty Persian restaurants.
author: Paola N.

description: This is the worst Persian restaurant I've seen very bad service no experience in and they're acting like a five-star restaurant but there not and their Price is very expensive and the food is not that good I ordered my food and they make a wrong order for me after 30 minutes of waiting
author: Mike A.

description: I love this place and it's way underrated. You'll never the have wait in line and the food is delicious. I've gone to all the Persian food spots in SF, and I'm from LA (where there's a ton of Persian food). The dishes here are delicious and the staff is friendly.
author: N J.

description: Ordered a lamb dish. It came cold and was overpriced for the quality.
author: Tracy B.

description: While we found the atmosphere to be slightly lacking (there were steady customers for a Thursday but it still felt empty and a bit dated) the food quickly won us over. We had the shirazi salad -onion, tomato and salad-cucumbers lightly pickled in their dressing. Delightful- very refreshing and light. The hummus was also very good, and went well with the provided bread. My husbands Fesenjoon (traditionally made with chicken) was delightful - sweet and rich, slightly tart. I had the Joojeh Soltani (one chicken breast and one ground beef kabob) and the chicken was just outstanding. The ground beef was good as well. We had fantastic service as well. Our only complaint was a sub-par wine selection and no beer menu to supplement it. Either way we shall return. We heard several patrons remarking about soups/stews and we will enjoy trying.
author: Shaz P.

description:
Great baghali polo with basmati rice. But I'm not happy with utensils and plates. Were very old and had a feeling of dirty. 
And also decorations and atmosphere is not really Persian style. 
But service and food is good. Tnx.
author: Solia S.

description: Writing a review as I stand at the front waiting for someone to acknowledge I am here even though I get an occasional glance that should be enough to realize someone is waiting. It's been about 20 minutes. I have this general experience in SF Persian restaurants: bad service. There bathroom is also right next to the waiting area and someone just changed a baby diaper so there is a remnant smell I have to endure while I wait too... I have just finished reviewing my entire experience so far and...still no acknowledgement. Frustrating. Not like I have anything else to do tonight. If this was not a preorder, I would leave.
author: Yrev T.

description: Great location, atmosphere and service. the food quality is great too but it can vary. The best in this restaurant is the crispy rice with pomegranate sauce.. It's so gooood.
author: Ahmad A.

description:
Albooooorz ! 

One of the best !!!!! Their appetizers , fooooddd OMG ! ;) 


Have some pomegranate juice and enjoy your lamb chops :) 
The bar guy (elderly) is funny :). Whenever I go this place , I really enjoy it !
author: Jay M.

description: We ate here with my gf's family from the east coast, who hadn't had Persian cuisine before, and they seemed to like it. Kabobs with the usual bountiful rice, hummus, tadik with fesenjan, etc. I had the Baghali Polo With Lamb Shank, which was delicious. The lamb was extremely tender and flavorful. The wait staff was extremely kind and attentive without being overbearing, and the decor was attractive and provided a great atmosphere.
author: Ken L.

description: Alborz is one of the few Persian places in SF. The staff here are super friendly and very accommodating. Azar joon is always welcoming and tries to make people's experience there special. I have been to Alborz with my friends several times and they all enjoyed the food. The food is not of top quality Persian food, but it is satisfactory and delicious. Their kababs are ok, but I am not actually a big fan of their stews (khoresh).
author: Bita G.

description:
good food. nice people.
i have been going there since they first opened up around 12 years (?) ago....
author: Mehran F.

description:
This place is off da sheezy eh. The tahdig entree is bomb -- three stews for 15 bucks with tahdig, it can't be beat! Also, their kabobs are delicious. If you've never tried persian food, this is a must! 

I also go here pretty religiously every Saturday post-workout. Gotta get dem gainz #yolo
author: Sam F.

description: so-so food. The eggplant appetizer is generally good in most Persian places but this one was really bad. The chicken koobideh was the only redeeming part of the meal. Service is great but bad bad food.
author: Aparna B.

description: Ambiance and service was great, but the food didn't do it for me. Average at best. Had the plater for two and most of the meat was pretty dry. It wasn't terrible, but I would probably spend a bit more and go to Lavash.
author: Riaz L.

description:
This spot is by my work and I finally went! I ordered Doogh, khoreshte bademjoon, salad shirazi, and ghormeh sabzi on tahdig.

The tahdig is NOON TAHDIG (bread tahdig) which got huge points from me. 
The Ghormeh Sabzi was also really good, no complaints.
The salad shirazi had a bit too much olive oil in it for my taste.
The Kashke bademjoon was fine- not my favorite.
The Doogh was excellent

The restaurant was cute and very clean, with persian decor, the servers were very nice and accommodating. The food came out quickly and I was in and out of there in half an hour as I was in a bit of a rush. Would definitely go back next time I'm at work and craving persian food.
author: Shayan S.

description:
After coming here a couple of times, I decided to finally write a review. 

Food: we always get tadeeg with two different types of stew and shirazi salad or mast e moosir as appetizers. We then order a soltani and kabob barg (or if i remember correctly they have a special for two) as entrees. We usually skip out on dessert but sometimes have tea if we are in a large group and want to stay longer to hangout/talk. The food has always been delicious.

Customer service: they have always considered our requests and been very friendly. We appreciate the smiles on their face to create a friendly environment. 

Price: I think it's moderate and fair. It is not too pricy, and if you are in the bay area you should be able to afford it 

I definitely recommend this restaurant to all the Persian food lovers!
author: Kiana R.

description:
The waitress  did not smile, the bus boy did not smile. 
The ground beef kabob was bland.  
The pita bread and the rice were not special.
Given the fact that the restaurant was almost empty, I expected better service.
author: A D.

description:
I like this spot. Don't let the exterior fool you. The interior isn't run down at all.  I've only ever gotten their chicken and beef kabobs and it tastes like home cooking to me.  They give an unreasonably large amount of rice with the kabobs but lots of Persian restaurants do that.  Apparently rice is flows freely from the heavens and you leave what you can't eat for the gods.  I haven't heard Odin complain yet so I'm OK with it. The flavors are on point for Persian food.  Both Maykadeh and Lavash are also good choices for Persian food but I prefer this spot.

Persian pro-tip: When getting kabobs ask for a raw egg yolk and mix it with your rice.  Double butter!
author: John K.

description: I go here a lot for lunch as I work nearby, and the occasional business lunch. I've always enjoyed everything on the menu. The staff is good the lady who was our waitress in particular. My only complaints are the the music was unnecessarily loud and I didn't particularly care for it. Also the bathroom is filthy. Apart from that I like the interior of the restaurant, the food and the service.
author: Sophia D.

description: Hi guys, yesterday we (5 friends)were in Alborz restaurant in Vanness ave. We wanted to eat there because we love their foods and service. But yesterday service was awful despite server is older. Eventhough they have a table server did not want to set up tables for us and made us to wait about half an hour. I didnt expect that much rude behavior from him. During the table also server didnt want to bring what we ask. We we asked him to bring some cut onions for Koobidah he brough us whole onions without chopping them. It was very frustrating and disrespectful. How can normal person act like this?! Server killed our inspire for this restaurant
author: Abror E.

description: I tried a couple of dishes at alborz and everything was absolutely amazing. My main dish was chicken kabob with rice and everything was moist and cooked perfectly. We accidentally ordered an appetizer with meat and the server took it without a fit and was pleased to bring us another vegetarian option. Also the cook checked on us to make sure everything tasted fine, I was very pleased with service and the food will be coming back.
author: Lovely V.

description:
Went to the movies at the AMC across the way and ventured over to Alborz to try something new.  Based on the quality of everything from service, food, and ambiance, I don't know how this place was not slammed packed on a Saturday night at 6:30.

If you are like me, and not really knowing what Persian food is all about, it can be intimidating with the menu items being in Persian, but are clearly described in English.  But I went with the lamb shank stew and eggplant not remembering what it was in Persion, but the server entertained me by complimenting my jumbled attempt at trying to say it.  The meat was fall off the bone tender in a tomatoe broth and the eggplant was nice in all of its glory when I dumped it all over my basmatti rice.  My fiancee had the cornish hen which was fan-freakin tastic.  When it was on the menu as one skewer for her meal I didn't think it was enough food, but it really was.  We also shared the appetizer platter which had all sorts of good stuff including dolmeh, olives, and more that I can't tell you what they were hahaha.  We also had some hummus, which goes good with everything!

It was a little pricey, but I still enjoyed our meal very much.
author: Scott F.

description:
First time eating dinner at this restaurant .  Pita bread and onions were brought out in a dirty napkin.  We told the waiter please give us a clean one.  We had the chicken kabobs and ground meat kabobs .....delicious !  We had a wonderful glass of their white wine .  

The food at this restaurant is really good !  However they need to Spend a little bit of time cleaning all the cob webs and not so crisp clean look.  Maybe I'll go back .... Maybe not.
author: Susan M.

description: This place reeks of mediocrity. The food is just OK and not super authentic. Sucks that SF does not have too many Iranian food options that are actually good. I've had better Persian food from an international super market in Berkeley. Over priced for what you get IMHO. If you are Iranian don't go there unless you want to be disappointed.
author: Sia M.

description:
If you are looking for a great Persian food in the city, please do NOT come here.  Go to either Maykadeh or Lavash, or even Anar. I do not like Alborz and I will tell the reason.

Every time ( I've been here 4 times in 6 years) I come here, I regret coimg after I eat and pay the bill.

1- The waitress/ staff/ manager woman acts like she knows me, and the last time I was there, as soon as she saw me at the door she asked with a sarcasm in her tone " Oh, were you here yesterday??" It was very annoying that she asked such a weird question right even before she says hello or take me to a table. I was not there the day before ( I don't really need to go there everyday!) or even if I was, it was not any of her business.

2- Each time when the food comes, it's either cold, or old. Yes, OLD. Three times out of the four times that I was here, the rice was looking and tasting old, like left over from the night before. As a Persian, and someone who eats rice almost every day, I can definitely tell the difference between freshly cooked and old rice. I was never satisfied with quality of food specially rice here. Kabobs are very greasy and too salty. I've also tried their Khoreshts but again, I'm not quiet happy. Something always lacks in the food here. It's either a flavor, or ingredient, or even the service. 

3- Prices are high for the quality. You can get the same amount of food but twice as much better quality at Maykadeh or Lavash. Sometimes Lavash  has even bigger portions for lower prices. 

I'm sorry that I'm writing this review, but you guys need to think about the taste of your foods. The flavors are not quiet right. If your chef is not Persian, try to hire a Persian chef!
author: Helen M.

description: The Yelp price for Ghormesabzy was $13.95 with rice, but when we picked it up to go they charged us $15.95 for a very small portion. We called to complain and the manager was unsympathetic. I would've given them 3 stars but they get 1 star for their bad customer service.
author: Liana B.

description:
Decent Persian food with decent service. Nothing here really blew me away flavor-wise, though I did appreciate the handful of vegetarian options available as I'd just stopped eating meat (yes, I chose a Persian restaurant as my first dining out experience after giving up meat--clearly I didn't think this through).

We got/tried the Kashk Bodemjan, Maygoo, Khoresht Bodemjan with Zereshk Polo and Aash Resteh. The Khoresht Bodemjan was the standout dish, a perfect stew to ward off the evening chill. 

Decor was pretty without being fussy, and service was pretty attentive and friendly. If you're in the area and craving something neither Western nor Far Eastern, this is a good contender.
author: Josephine L.

description: One of the things I most miss since leaving San Francisco is the Shirin Polo with Baked Chicken at Alborz. I discovered this dish the first time I stumbled across this gem and never looked back. I try to make sure that any trip back to SF (I now live in Australia) includes a trip to Alborz. The food has never disappointed and the service matches the culinary excellence for a warm heart to go with the happy stomach.
author: Rose S.

description: Visiting from Texas! We had lunch here! I tried their zereshk pollo chicken! Was so good. Nice atmosphere and really good service
author: Amir T.

description:
We were there a few times there 
Is two maneger there sometimes a woman and sometimes a man, the woman is so good and polite and kind but the man is so rude and not respectful and wicked . My friend said maybe because we are gay he is so rude .
author: Orod B.

description: Great dishes to order: Fesenjoon with meatballs, Ash Reshteh (Soup)
author: V V.

description: This place never lets down. The food is fresh, meat is seasoned very well and is flavorful, and the service is good. Very clean and nice set up inside. My go to kabob spot in the city.
author: Ahmed K.

description: Super delicious Persian food full of flavor. I ordered delivery and everything was well packaged and hot. I ordered the Zereshk Polo and it was some of the best chicken I've had. 3 good meaty size Chicken thighs cooked to perfection. Super moist and flavorful as it appears they are covered/stewed in some type of gravy. A hefty serving of their infamous saffron rice cooked with barberries. Tangy but not overwhelming. That rice is good with a little bit of that chicken gravy poured over it. Also ordered the Baba Ganoush and it met my expectations. Smoky, garlicky and all well puréed. I love this stuff! They threw in some of their Sabzi, pats of butter and some pita which I've heard is customary when you eat at their restaurant. Lots of food and it made my belly smile. Definitely looking forward to visiting the restaurant and ordering delivery for those rainy (lazy) days.
author: Jorge P.

description:
Best persian food you can find in the city.  There arent a lot of options for persian restaurants but Alborz is the most consistent food i can find.  The soltani is always great and surprisingly their salmon kabob is excellent.  My family and I come here all the time and we have always been pleased.  Another good thing is that you can come here with a big group and they  can always accommodate.

You shouldn't expect much as far as atmosphere, but if you're looking for solid persian food in san francisco this is the only place i would recommend.
author: Yasi N.

description: It was fine. A friend took me to this place. Hard to park. Drove around for 30 minutes. Was not worth the effort trying to have dinner in the city. NOt much into this kind of food, but it was ok to good.
author: Eric H.

description:
A really nice, relaxed, comfortable serving of Persian food and hospitality.  Very well done, excellently attended.  You could do much worse that a stop here. 

The wines are nice, the food authentic, and the prices very agreeable.  Make a stop here and you'll be treated and fed well.
author: James M.

description:
Iranian reviewer here. Went here with my parents so I am giving their review as well. 
Dad: Solid restaurant. Prices were a little high (his opinion since he paid), but he enjoyed his lamb and said he would come back 
Step-mom: Got the chicken kabob and she loved it. She said it was moist and one of her favorite spots. She said she will def' come bac
Me: This is not my favorite persian spot in the city, but it offers a tradtional persian meal that is 4/5 for me. I would recommend the soltani since it gives you a 1 koobideh and 1 filet mignon. 
All: we all loved the doogh here. Made very well.
author: Soroosh A.

description:
Great food! If you are looking for an authentic Persian food with Traditional look, Alborz is the best place for you! Compared to Lavash the food is more authentic here.

But in my opinion the utensils need to be renewed.
author: Bonyan Z.

description: Service is always good.  Their koobideh is the best in sf in my opinion. The yogurt cucumber and salad shirazi is always on point.  The chicken kabob always seems kinda dry and lacks flavor.  Prices are good compared to other sf Persian restaurants.
author: David S.

description: Ice food, well cooked and nice taste. The place is crowded on weekends and the orders are late to be prepared but still worth to wait
author: Diamond J.

description: Went here for my graduation dinner with a party of 25 people. Good was good but a bit over cooked and on the dry side. Customer service was very good however and haaalllll kardeem!
author: Omid T.

description: I remember my friends wife cooked Amazing Rice with saffron and raisins in it , i wanted that again, so i found this Alborz on yelp, the items i wanted were there, a little different, on their menu on yelp was one price , thinking it was valid, I ordered 2 orders of rice and one small small, salad consisting of tomatos, cucumbers, onion lemon juice, i go to pick it up the bill was $23.87 for 2 orders of rice and small salad ! i said what , on your menu on yelp is lower, they said oh that is an old menu, What you should update it, I think its a Ploy to get new customers, they do it on purpose. the rice was just ok, it didn't need nuts and orange peel.I shouldn't have to ask if the prices are up to date online,i've noticed some restaurants do the same with the menu printed outside on the wall , i just ask you to update the prices to reflect the real price.
author: Daniel M.

description:
Very nice and yummy food . Service is nice but sometimes under stuff . But they all are super sweet people. Cucumber yogurt salad is amazing and super good. Rice chicken and lamb is good too. No complains yet ever . One time out of 20 the meat  was  a bit dry but is ok. Happens . 

Also their tea is really good - who likes a real tea going w dinner .
author: Tetyana G.

description: Excellent food. Only 1 server and food runner/busser was working the entire restaurant. So service was not necessarily friendly, but it was efficient.  Took a while to get the check but we were enjoying our wine and was not in a hurry. The food spoke for itself so we will be back. About $15-$20 a plate for entrees but portions are big and wine selection was nice and reasonably priced.
author: Daniel A.

description:
I came here with a few friends and I must say that it is hit or miss.

The beef koobideh and chicken koobideh were "meh" and not too great.

However, the appetizers and the stews were amazing.


If you come, please get the Khorest Ghemeh (Yellow split pea and diced beef stew with spices) and the Ghormeh Sabzi ( Green herbs and kidney beans with veal shank)

It is heavenly with their saffron basmati rice.

The kebabs here were soso, not the best, but the stews here are very good. 


Overall a decent 3 star persian place in SF
author: Sam N.

description:
I was hoping if there was a zero star !!
 
I went there with my brother on Saturday night after we took our sets 10min later a young lady got our orders and guess what ?????????! 48 min later we got our food !!!!!! 
I will never come back there again !
author: Nassim I.

description:
I went in after ordering a Koobideh after looking at the menu on Yelp.  Apparently the price listed is wrong.  I told this to the waiter/server.  He said take it up with the owner and asked if I still wanted my order.  He didn't seem to care to want my business so 
I left.  Probably the last time I go here.
author: Paul R.

description:
I would give 0 stars to this restaurant!!! Bad customer service.... way too arrogant people with such an attitude! Waiter is a random guy with huge tattoos under his yellow stained and dirrty "white" shirt! His nails are long and dirrty underneath! The other waiter doesnt speak english! Now the food...
Maybe some of you think im crazy but you are suppose to rinse rice specially coming out of huge bags! Rice is not usually clean.... and at alborz u can taste how unwashed it is like you eat dirtt from the floor. The koobideh is fine but when you see how nasty the waiter is you just lose your appetite and all u imagine is how nasty it is in the kitchen. I had one spoon of rice and one piece of meat and left my plate there. Nobody bothered to ask why i didnt eat my food! They get offensive if you give them a feedback! Sad though since its a great location I would totally take advantage of it to make lots of business!
author: Diana I.

description:
Went there to celebrate the Birthday with 20 people. Order 20 plates plus appetizers Teas, Coffees, Sodas and couple of deserts. But got my own cake.

************
GOT CHARGED $1.75 PER PERSON FOR CUTTING A CAKE ON TOP OF 20% TIP THAT THEY ADDED. ?!?!?!?!?!?
************

ABSURD.

Plus they talk crap about us in Farsi (If I do not look like one does not mean I don't speak it)

Never going back there again.
author: Erik K.

description:
Took some clients here for their first exposure to Persian food. I was disappointed by the quality of food. The prices are very high and parking next to impossible. There simply need to be more Persian Food choices in the city! 
The service was decent. All in all, I probably wont be going back unless I hear some changes have been made.
author: Jamak G.

description:
A nice, clean, conveniently close spot to get my koobideh fix. It isn't the best koobideh I have ever had, but it definitely fulfills my craving.

Servers are always nice, as are the owners. Not that crowded.. Ever. So at least you're always guaranteed to get a seat right when you walk in.

They do serve lavash, with onions and butter before bringing out the food. The meat is tender and you can cut through your koobideh with a fork. It is a bit overpriced for what you're getting, but the convenience of it being so close to my apartment makes it worth it.
author: Sarah H.

description: Both the food and service here were excellent; the waitstaff was knowledgeable and friendly, checking up on us frequently and greeting us like we were family. The food came out quickly and was very well prepared, and plated very nicely. The descriptions on the menu were also very helpful (as opposed to some other exotic cuisine restaurants, which can be very confusing to eat at). We also loved the atmosphere! Try the rose water ice cream, too, for dessert. This is definitely somewhere I'd be willing to come back to again.
author: Kay P.

description:
A wonderful dining experience. Wait staff was very helpful and truly delighted to be there. Not like some restaurants (looking at you, Lavash) that think they are you good to be true. 

I wish I could have had a little bit of the whole menu. I had a chicken kabob plate and was impressed as to the tenderness of the chicken.  The rice was made to perfection, unlike that other restaurant.  

Highly recommended and you can thank be later.
author: David A.

description: LOVEEE this place! It is super close to my house and so yummy! I always get the koobideh entree and it never dissapoints. Being Persian myself, I love having a little taste of home so close. Whenever I order take-out it is ready within 10-15 minutes too which is a plus!
author: Sheila S.

description: Great food, and great service that has stayed persistent over the years. My favorite Persian restaurant in SF.
author: SpottieMatic X.

description:
I like to go to Alborz. It's never too busy and the service is always very attentive. The atmosphere is comfortable so it makes for a low key date night. Whenever we go, we always order the mast o musir which lasts through the entirety of the meal. I usually order the prawns kabob with the rice, orange shavings, and pistachios. My partner gets one of the bargs (chicken, usually). 

Portions are on the larger side, which is nice, because each plate is about $19. Can't speak to the desserts or the wine selection but if you're in the area and want Persian food, I'd highly reccomend.
author: Tommy C.

description:
I don't understand how this restaurant got so many good reviews. Maybe these people are "good customers".

This restaurant is totally overpriced and the size of the food is about half of a regular Persian plate.
author: Rokgoo R.

description: Whenever I come here or pass by Alborz it is generally empty. This kind of made me wonder how good the food was actually going to be.  I must say I found the food to be absolutely delicious and the service was decent.  I would definitely go back and I would suggest the kebabs or house specialty entrees as they were delicious.
author: David F.

description: I love this place, and I drive across town to go there because the food is terrific! I especially like the Kefta Kabob with baked tomatoes and rice and salad. I also like the management - they are so nice and accommodating, and it's neat that they get so excited when you walk in every time. I mean, how cool is that?
author: Julie M.

description: Huge plates with really good food! I tried every dish from their menu and all of them are so delicious, cooked in old persian traditions. Nice service staff, they are always glad to help you. Location is perfect and place is big , hostess always will find seats for you.
author: Christine L.

description: The food is very good here. I love the special sampler appetizer which comes with different cold Persian starters.
author: Nazanin E.

description: Probably the best Persian food in SF. The salmon and joojeh are always good. The egg plant is also a good appetizer.
author: Sami S.

description: Well, I hate to write a bad review for any business, but for this restaurant I Must. the food was not good at all, the rice was not cooked enough and on top of it they over charged me $20.00 on a take out menu of $80.00. The old lady explained the price on the take out menu is not the same as we sell here. they cheat. don't go here.
author: Allen Y.

description:
Food: Amazingly good and authentic, and juicy.
Service: Great and welcome service animals as well.
Ambiance: Elegant and classy/chic.
author: CR C.

description:
The service staff is sweet and I am sorry to do this but I cannot recommend that you go to this place if you are looking for Persian Food.  I had gone there a couple of years ago and it was ok - nothing to draw me back in, but not terrible.  

Then a friend wanted to meet there as a convenient spot on Persian New Year because a couple of the other places we wanted to go to were packed.  It was beyond dead in there - for a reason. The food in my opinion has gone for so-so to just plain not good... I hard time eating even half of my dish and my tummy was not happy with me for the little I did eat.  :-(
author: N A.

description: The food is good and the owners are the loveliest people, after dinner have the Persian tea delicious!
author: Gina N.

description: Delicious kebabs, kubideh. Recommend Zaban for appetizer. Nice atmosphere, good service. Visiting again very soon.
author: Erik H.

description:
Delicious meats, the spiced ground beef and thin sliced filet was very tender and well seasoned (cooked perfectly as well).

More rice than you could ever eat, not to mentions grilled tomatoes, lots of onions and a cucumber salad. They don't skimp on the extras and are happy to bring you more.

Don't forget to try the delicious baklava and cap it off with their tea (great way to end a meal of this magnitude).

Servers and hostess are friendly and attentive, will return and recommend you do as well!
author: Jeff B.

description:
Had the Kashk Bademjan (roasted eggplant topped with whey, mint, fried onions, and chopped walnuts) and Koobideh (two kabobs of ground beef seasoned with onions, spices.  My friend has the cornish hen and bee kabobs combo which was a better option to get the best of both worlds so you don't overload on just beef.  The rice was somewhat overcooked but the rest of the meal was tasty which made up for it. 

 I could be wrong but I remember the portions were slightly larger last time I went.  Nonetheless, it's tough to find a decent Persian let alone any Persian food in the city, so Alborz is still an option.  Probably skip the yogart soda next time since it's on the saltier side for my taste.
author: Stephanie C.

description:
It is currently 2014 and San Francisco only has three Persian restaurants; one is Lavash and it is located basically at the ocean (WAY too far away) and the other is  Maykadeh which is more of a 2-3 stars dining experience. Alborz is decent food, it is overpriced however when you are the best of three restaurants in the vicinity I think your allowed to increase the price. 

Order the koo koo sabzi (herb egg dish/vegetarian), chicken koobideh (very moist ground chicken kebabs), all the rice dishes like baghali polo (lima beans in dill rice), shirin polo (sweet rice with orange peel and nuts) or zereshk polo (saffron and barberries rice) and the doogh (salty mint & yogurt drink). The menu is fairly vegetarian friendly for a Persian restaurant and most rice dishes can have salad as a substitution or 1/2 rice with 1/2 salad. 

If you want good Persian food go to the Santa Clara/San Jose area OR Glendale/Southern California, if you want good Persian food in San Francisco try Alborz.
author: Shannon Z.

description:
I have some Persian friends and they introduced me to some great food. This place is not what I have experienced, standard wise. I would expect that the people who gave this place great reviews to be either Persians or friends of the owner.

My boyfriend works near the restaurant so he has been wanting to try the place, but he was reludant to mention how the restaurant is almost empty and never checked on the reviews of this place.

When we arrived, the entire place was empty and the workers were standing behind the bar, chit chatting. It took them about a few seconds to realize we were standing at the booth waiting to be seated. When we finally got seated at the corner window of the floor, they offered us the menus and wandered off. Then a waiter returns to take our order. We ordered the following (not exact names off the menu):

Pita Bread (Complimentary): Who serves pita bread with butter with a side of onions? I just don't understand! I guess they expect you to order some hummus if you want to have the pita bread to go with something. It's such a cheap trick. I asked for some garlic sauce and they said I would have to order the yogurt elephant sauce. They were nice enough to bring me a tiny bit to try.

Grilled Prawns (appetizer): $12 for 4 prawns with cocktail sauce and a bit of salad in the middle. Completely not worth it. The taste was good, but I think I could have bought the same quality of cocktail shrimps from Costco.

Chicken Kabob: The chicken were tender and served with a large portion of rice and one roasted tomato on the side

Veggie Kabob: Roasted eggplant, green pepper, onion, mushroom, and tomato. The proportion of the plate is completely off. The veggie takes up half of the RIM of the plate and then the rest of the plate is filled with a big portion of rice. Are they trying to make me satisfy by stuffing me with rice and not with flavor? The vegetables are bland and it taste like it's missing the basic flavor of salt (and I'm the kind of person who's sensitive to saltiness).

Overall, from the outside, the place looks like fine dining. They reflect that on the price, but doesn't reflect that on the food. Which concludes you to have one overpriced restaurant with food that can be sold at food trucks for $5 a plate.
author: Elaine Y.

description: Before checking out a show at the Regency, we went in here for a quick bite. Koobideh, taadig and the lamb tongue stew are solid. The latter being super tender showing that they cooked it with care for a long time. I thought Tommy's Joynt was the only choice in the area for a while but good to see Alborz is a decent option too before shows
author: Kim N.

description:
The place was really nice! Lamb fillet was excellent, but it was $23. Is that because saffron costs so much?  Really, it was some of the most tender lamb I've had. We also had the vanilla ice cream with rice noodle and rose water. What a combo!  It was great.

Good looking and quiet inside, not many people when I was there, and you could not hear Van Ness outside. Take a date here before going to the Regency or the Opera.  It's not a dress down place, but nobody in this town cares of you do!
author: Mark M.

description: Delish! Some of the best persian food around the Bay! Worth the drive to SF! A must try when you're in the area.
author: Victoria N.

description:
This place is perfect in every way since it's easy to find as it's right on the corner, and it's located near a parking garage that's only a two minute walk away from the restaurant! It's also classy and romantic, the food is good, the service is attentive, and the food comes out fairly quick. I'm so glad that I found this place by doing a search of what's nearby. Since we had tickets for the Edwardian ball across the street, this was the best choice for us! BTW, the Edwardian ball was amazing! That will be my 600th review which I'm getting really close to! 

Anyways, my husband and I started out with the pickle and olive appetizer. It think it was $6.50. It came with baby pickles, feta cheese, and delicious black olives. We also ordered the hummus for around the same price. The portion was huge and it came with fresh slices of cucumbers and tomato's. They served us complimentary flat bread with onions and butter. For the entree, we both got the beef koobideh for $14.95. It came with two big and tender pieces of meat, plain basmati rice, and a grilled tomato. It was delicious. 

For dessert, he got the baklava and coffee and I got Persian ice cream. I've never had Persian ice cream before and it sounded good, so I had to try it. It tasted like regular vanilla ice cream with a hint of rosewater. It was good, but I was full by that time so I only took a few bites and then gave the rest to my husband. He was still a little hungry after eating all that food, lol! There is a second level to this place for a better view. I wish that we would've sat up there instead. If you need to use the restroom here, you have to ask for the key at the bar. Also, they only serve beer and wine here.  If you end up parking in the garage nearby, be sure to leave there before 10:30p.m as that's when they close.
author: Butterfly A.

description:
Although this place can be missed from the outside, it tries to establish itself as a fine dining restaurant.  The appetizer with the eggplant was good, but the torshee, which are pickled vegetables, was disappointing because they were chopped as a condiment and drowned in a salty sauce that cannot be eaten alone as a dish.  The tender and juicy koobideh was seasoned well.  However, the chicken joogeh was dry and tough compared to most restaurants.  The barg lacked flavor even though it was cooked medium rare.  If you ask for the basmati rice to be substituted with salad, please ask them to have the salad dressing on the side or else it will be drowned in vinegar.  

The service is slow and unfriendly, almost with disdain.  The waiter will coerce you into ordering things even though you ask questions to explore your options.  The decor and ambiance is clean, quiet and simple without any flair or authentic Persian feel.  Parking can be tough on the street.
author: Jenny L.

description: This place was a disappointment. I would recommend to go elsewhere. There are definitely better Mediterranean restaurants. The service was good, but the food was sub-par.
author: Michael G.

description: Location is great...food is delicious...but staff need to vent a little friendlier...the guy who greeted me at the door when we arrived didn't say or anything...just took me to the table, left the menus and just walked away.  It was a bit weird. The head waiter was nicer...but the other one, not so much.  Only reason I didn't give it a five star rating.
author: Ara L.

description:
I wanna move this place into Reno.  This was just amazing.  I have only had Persian food a handful of times but this was just a great experience.

Service was reserved and maybe a tad slow on the refreshing of the water but still good.

The food was quality.  We went for lunch.  Loved the Turkish Coffee.

I was with friends so I really didn't wanna geek out on Yelping so I wasn't able to take detailed notes.  But suffice it to say...the food was excellent.


I will be back.  And that says alot, because when I go to San Francisco, I have hundreds of choices I have never had before...but this place is worth the drive.

I will tell all of my friends to save a few extra bucks and try the lunch here.
author: Robert S.

description:
Poor quality lamb, flavorless and dry.
Falafel was dry and crumbly.
Price of food inversely proportional to food quality!
Forgot to bring utensils!!
Poor service...1 hour for delivery!!!
Neither Greek nor Persian, just bad.
author: Emily S.

description:
Seems like they microwave the food--sauce was lukewarm but the chicken was very, very hot (and dry)

Staff was very friendly.

They give lots of rice, and the rice was good, not necessarily great (most reviews seem to rave about the rice).  So you can definitely leave the place feeling full.
author: Amanda B.

description:
Seven of us went to Alborz for late lunch on Sunday of Canaval in SF. The ambience was pretty average, but comfortable. We ordered different kabobs and stews. We asked the waitress as why the stews don't have lamb shank in them as Alborz in Berkeley does. We were told that the Berkeley branch puts lamb shanks in their stews when they run out of regular stew meat ! We later found out that it's no the case. To avoid the haggle of who pays the bill (Persian custom :), I went to the bar and gave the waitress my credit card. Later on I went to sign for the card and she had added 18% for service charge/tip. That came to $38 on our bill. She explained to me that there is a 18% service charge for parties of 6 or more. I was in too much of a hurry to check and see if it says on their menu. I also did not see that mentioned on their Yelp menu.
Anyways, the food was ok, nothing special. The prices out $3-$4 less that Meykadeh in North Beach and way cheaper for some items (barg, soltani kababs). We all agreed that Alborz in Berkeley has better food and in a more crowded location with nicer ambiance.
author: Sam N.

description:
I love me some Persian food, especially koobideh kebabs, but why do they always have to be so expensive?! I stopped by Alborz on a weekday evening with my sister. The restaurant was mostly empty at 8pm when we arrived, but we were promptly greeted, seated, and presented with the menus. They also brought us lavash bread and butter very quickly, as well as our ice water.

I went with my usual koobideh and my sister decided to venture into unknown territories with a beef stew of lentils and tomatoes and eggplant. It didn't look pretty, but she seemed to enjoy it a lot. The funniest part of the meal was that her dish came with a really squishy round object that we couldn't identify. I stabbed it really easily with my fork, but I couldn't figure out what it was. She ended up breaking it open to finally figure out that it was a preserved lemon. Not sure how it added to the dish as I didn't really taste any lemony or citrus flavors, but it did provide some entertainment value for a few minutes as our brains dreamed up outlandish ideas of what it could be. My koobideh was juicy and delicious. The rice was perfectly cooked, though the saffron flavor was nonexistent. And of course, the roasted tomato was tasty. I was slightly disappointed that their portion sizes weren't huge enough for me to have leftovers for lunch the next day, given the prices. But that could also be a testament to how tasty the food was.

I'd consider returning to Alborz for lunch sometime if their lunch prices are lower than their dinner prices. Then again, Alborz is definitely a "nice" restaurant that you could take someone on a date. I felt under dressed in shorts and a t-shirt.
author: Leslie H.

description:
Fantastic food and service!

The food was prepared absolutely perfectly and it was delicious! Very authentic with the correct level of spices, I look forward to going back again and again.  

My favorite Persian restaurant in the City.
author: Ali T.

description:
I went there with a large group of ~20. 

I was very pleased by the bone-in chicken kabob dinner that I had. It was grilled to perfection - completely cooked through yet still very juicy - higher than average portion!

Their menu was reasonably priced - $22 including tax&tip.

I would definitely go back on my next visit to San Francisco!
author: Amir T.

description:
I was in town for a conference and  took 7 of my American friends to this place recommended by my friends. the service is amazing. our waitress was super nice and accommodating to the needs of all 7 and one vegetarian. mix appetizers, Tahdeeg, yougurt was amazing. we ordered family style Barg, shishlik, kobideh and shish kabob with all variety of rice. my favorit was shishlik and barg. every thing tasted good. my friends loved bakhlava. the only thing i did not care for was Faloodeh. 
i will recommend it to all my friends.
author: Aida G.

description: We have come here for years. Today's visit however was very different from ones before. Our food did not taste the way it has tasted before. For some reason everything did not taste right. The rice tasted like it was reheated or something. I don't know if that had anything to do with us being the first ones in the restaurant as they opened. We were very disappointed because we come here every time we come into the city. Also, I felt like our whole meal was very over priced for what we were getting. We had actually ordered a salad with a skewer of chicken for $20. When it came out it barely had any lettuce. "Salad" with chicken for $20?!? No thank you! Our serve has us sit in the corner which would have been fine if we continued to get refines on our drinks but we didn't. We are from this culture and know what real authentic kabobs are suppose to taste like....unfortunately...today we felt like we were cheated.
author: Amanda N.

description: FOOD POISONING!  food was okay- although I would recommend spending your money elsewhere. I should also add that I got horrible food poisoning 2 hours after dinner and was up all night sick and sick a day or so after. I had chicken. Anyways- stay far away! Food isn't worth the money they charge nor is it worth the possible food poisoning as they obviously don't take measures to ensure food safety.i should note I saw other reviews claim they didn't feel well after eating there after initially writing my review.
author: Lo Z.

description: Loved dinner! Everything was great started with the roasted eggplant plate and oh my god it was freakin awesome! Very tasty and creamy  then ordered the chicken & beef plate and it was perfect! Tendered and juicy. Overall great food, environment, and Persian music! Will be back
author: Zohan E.

description: Food is awesome. I have no point of comparison but looking at some of the reviews the service must have improved a lot! I was served like a king. I ordered as soon as I was ready. The food came really quick and was delicious. And they checked on me every 5 minutes. So, perfect performance. I really recommend it.
author: Juan C.

description: Okay experience. The food was EXCELLENT (I ordered the Fesenjan), but the service was just...odd. We were the only ones in the restaurant at 6PM on a Monday yet the stoic and unsmiling man who served us seemed to be inconvenienced by our presence. Given it's a pretty big restaurant, it just felt awkward and uncomfortable. I don't think I will return, sadly, despite the deliciousness of the food.
author: Jen D.

description: Great place.  Chicken is just right, tender, nicely spiced.  Lots of rice.  Not cheap, but good value.
author: John O.

description: Came in here 35 minutes before closing, the server who was busy chatting tells us "they're closed" when they clearly close at 10pm. Why don't you just write that it closes at 9:30 then! Wasted time finding parking and walking for no reason. Wish I could give you a review on the food but clearly they don't care about customer service or the fact that someone took time to come into their restaurant instead they decide to choose when they stop serving customers or maybe it was because we weren't dressed nice like other people in the restaurant since we had just gotten off work. Regardless, this type of treatment is unacceptable and I can say that I will NEVER walk into that place to eat even if it's a last resort.
author: Jasnoor S.

description: Mediocre and very expensive for the quality. Came with a large group and there was an overwhelming verdict of meh.
author: Daniel N.

description: I am a huge fan of this place. The quality is consistent, the servers are so incredibly friendly, and there is never a wait (why?). They are also extremely kind to our one year old, which is a very big deal to us!
author: A B.

description: Food was great meat was tender and more importantly it was SUPER authentic. I went with a Persian friend who ordered for us. I would recommend going here if you have the chance.
author: Erik A.

description: Really good restaurant with amazing Persian food! i am Persian and enjoyed the food here while Staying in SF.
author: Saeed M.

description: The sausage is pretty bomb! The chicken is soft and tender. The pomegranite juice is a nice fresh delight. The lamb was so-so (although it did fall off the bone) but the stew itself was really good!!
author: Stephen G.

description:
very dissappointing.  I used to refer friends here, and have eaten here several times and mostly enjoyed myself, but recently I've become less than satisfied.

I had lunch here recently on a weekday.  Maybe it was that it was an off-time, but things just didn't go quite right.

First, the tea was bitter. No, it wasn't too strong. It was bitter - meaning it was either poorly made or had sat around a long time.  We asked for new tea, and instead of making new tea, they watered down the overly bitter, bad-tasting tea, leaving us with watery bad tea.

Next, they brought me my rice.  It had a hair in it.  Not good.  They did bring me a new plate, but no sort of apology or anything for giving me rice with hair in it.

They didn't charge for the tea, but everything else was full-price (and no apology for blowing it twice).
author: Bob R.

description: If your in need for a Persian food fix it will do but it would not be my first choice for you foodies.  Go to Maykadeh instead! The chicken koobideh was burnt and dry. I was surprised they served it to me as I was the only one in the restaurant.
author: Kavon M.

description:
I came here once for a work party and it was honestly not bad. I came in with low expectations because a co-worker is not too fond of this place, but all in all it was a pleasant experience.

We got the combination platter for our appetizer which was very refreshing - I remember the bread they served with it went very well with the different foods they had in the combination.

The entree we got was the Alborz Plate - one skewer each of filet, chicken, breast, ground beef and rice - the filet of lamb, the ground beef and rice were very tasty. However, I found the chicken to be quite dry. & I don't quite know what the tomatoes were all about but they were not so good to me.

I did like the wine we got served and the staff seemed very pleasant. I also like the atmosphere of this restaurant - intimate and casual. I would visit here again but only if it was with a big group or work party and minus the chicken.
author: Junel S.

description:
I am writing a review over my latest 2 experiences here, which seems to sum up what the state of this restaurant unfortunately currently is.

Alborz...you really need to step up your service. And I mean that in the most basic way possible!

I enter...no hostess..some guy behind the bar...he goes to the back soon too. Since I just got a new phone im like eh whatever and mess around on it for 5 minutes thinking they will come to me then. Over 5 minutes passes nothing. Mind you, in this large restaurant there is only one other person sitting and he is merely paying his bill. After about 10 minutes. I decide to take a seat at one of the 50 open tables. 

I literally sit there (by myself) waiting for 20 minutes before anyone comes to me to give me water or a menu! Since I am not with anyone at the moment the only thing I have to entertain me is the dismal view of Van Ness st. Why is all the staff hiding in the back? There didnt seem to be a shortage of staff, up to 4 people seemed to have been assigned the front....bus boy, server, hostess..and there was barely any patrons..yet they all hide in the back?? I feel like there was a company foosball tournament going on back there or som shet. Though both times I went it was like this.

I order my food right when he hands me the menu in fear of having to wait another 20 minutes for him to ask me what I would like. I get the Soltani, which is a common Persian combination entree: basmatic saffron infused rice (persian rice so gewd), a grilled tomato, 1 skewer of barg (flattened steak cut), 1 skewer of koobideh (seasoned ground beef). Sometimes comes with onions and other stuff, tho not here.

The wait for the food itself was average. Food review:

Koobideh: 4/5 stars....seasoned well, tasty and juicy, though not super juicy/greasy. At the same time not amazing. Koobideh is good and cheap but usually I dont buy a bunch of koobideh cuz its not healthy, thad be like buying multiple hamburgers.

Barg: 1/5 stars. I ordered medium, this came well done. dry like rubber, and the meat tasted old! disgusting! one of the rare times i didnt finish my kabob. but actually this does happen from time to time, some restaurants have horrible barg, i dunno why.

Shish Kabob (from other time I went recently) : 3/5 stars

seemed to have been marinated in a way that was unusual for persian shish kabob. salty and wet. not typical shish kabob, tho wasnt too bad either. would not order again. Shish kabob comes with grilled bell pepper, onion etc.

I have yet to try the joojeh (chicken thigh) kabob, hopefully its good, cuz so far coming here I only enjoy the koobideh.

another note, the other time i came the hostess/waitress was this 30 somtin yr old persian chic in what seemed to be a dominatrix outfit. some (but definitely not most) persian women seemed confused fashion-wise, she was wearing a black top, this knarly black skirt, with tall black leather boots. kinda cracked me up, i dont really care though lol

the carpet and decor needs to be updated, looks liek its from a shitty casino in the 70's

anyway I asked for my bill and it took another 20 minutes to get there...yes while i look around and there are 2 other tables eating, NO ONE IN THE FRONT, ALL EMPLOYEES IN THE BACK TWIDDLING THEIR BALLS

one last thing, in order to get to the bathroom you need to go through this long corrider that passes by the bar/restaurant next door that serves deep dish pizza or somtin. I dont like this, the pizza is super appetizing but im in persian food mode..it F's with your brain. That's like being on a nice date, and then walking through a strip club. 

They dont accept amex. When I gave my bill with amex card, a new young man I had not seen before appeared and told me "Sorry, vee do nat except amax"...which lead me to believe this employee's sole duty at the restaurant is to let patrons know they dont accept amex. A very interesting job. Where were you when I needed to be seated or order?

oh yah one more thing...it's bloody expensive!

downgrade to 2.5 stars rounded down to 2

I won't be back until I've confirmed they have stepped up to the most basic form of restaurant service, vat iz dees?
author: Belito L.

description: This was my first time at Alborz and I will be back.  I had the Kashk Bademjan (roasted eggplant) to start and it was delicious. For my main course, I had the Ghorbe Sabzi. Yummy!!!  Flavorful and well prepared.  The waiter was very kind and attentive. Cant wait to go back!
author: Maya S.

description:
Wish there was a possibility of zero stars. 

One of the worst Persia Restaurants in the Bay Area.  
I will make this short 

I visited this restaurant on a Saturday around 1:00 p.m. 
You think at lunch time they will have more than one waiter helping out, but I guess that it just false hope. 
It took exactly 12 minute for the lady to come over and ask if we wanted anything to drink,  I even jokingly said "I thought you forgot about us" but she did not even blink. 

We ordered the Combination Platter as an appetizer and the Alborz Plate for the main course. We thought this way we will have a little taste of everything.

What a waste, the olives on the combination platter was the only edible thing on the plate and for the main dish the rice was just dry and tasted awful, like if it was cooked two days ago and they warmed it up in the microwave. The kabobs were even worse, not even worth mentioning. 

All these aside the waitress did not even come over once to check on us. 

I will definitely never go back to there or recommend it to anyone.
author: Nesa M.

description: Loved everything about Alborz! The food was seasoned and cooked to perfection and the waiters were helpful and friendly.
author: Wanda M.

description: Middle East and Eastern cuisines are my favorites, esp Afghani and Iranian, because they are so close to my country food and rich with various types of meals. I was craving for Iranian food and we decided to go to Albourz as my husband is familiar with their menu and know this place better. So, we went in and Azer khanim greet us in a very hospitable manner that made us feel special. She let us chose the place the we prefer to sit and then provided us with menu. As per my hubby's advice, we decided to have qeyma bademjand, and fesenjan (one of our fav. Iranian meal). We started our dinner with lavash that came with onion and parsley, and salted butter. I have no idea why they serve butter with onion, however, I enjoyed lavash with butter. We continued our food with combo appetizer, including yoghurt with cucumber, shahrezad (cucumber, tomato, onion mixed) and bademjan. I loved bademjan so much that I was almost full with this appetizer. As soon as we finished our appetizer, they brought main meal: fesenjan made from chicken and nuts, and qeyma bademjan made from meat, eggplant and beans, and basmati rice. Tell the truth, I was enjoyed fesenjan so much that ate almost all of it, didn't have any place for qeyma bademjan :)  I used to eat a lot fesenjan in my childhood as my grandmother was a master of this meal, and today it took me to my childhood. As there was no space for qeyma in our stomach, because the portion is really big enough even to share with two people, we decided to take away qeyma and rice. It's sin not to have tea and leave this fabulous place. So, after a while, we ordered tea and pakhlava. The tasted and smelled rose water that gives special pleasure to drink after taste food. The pakhlava wasn't Iranian, but was Turkish. I tried various pakhlavas in different Turkush restaurant, even at Turkish friends' party's. However, they are either too sweet or have less pistachios than should have. Today's pakhlava was the best one that I have ever tried in Bay Area, including Turkish friends (please, don't be offended my Turkish friends ). The pakhlava at Albourz isn't too sweet, it has just enough amount of sugar and fresh pistachios on it. I loved it so much that wanted to order a box of pakhlava, although I was full with food . Overall, I rate Alvourz 5 stars for great service, delicious food and hospitality, and I think they really deserve 5!
author: Moonlike I.

description:
I don't understand why the reviews are so spotty for Alborz; we go her quite frequently and have never received bad food or sub-standard service.  The only time we have to wait is when they have just seated a large party, and this is a blessing as we always go with our two young children, whom the staff treats like royalty.  The chicken barg is so tender and juicy that it is basically the only chicken my son will eat, the koobideh is always moist and flavorful.  Perhaps the critiques of the rice come from people not used to Persian rice?  Granted, the Gormeh Sabzi is not as good as Aunt Ashraf's but really, whose is?

At any rate, it is clean, quiet and yummy and hits the spot every time our family wants some Persian comfort food.
author: Saskia L.

description: I can't even begin to tell you how bad and rotten the food was. Koobideh smelled of old meat and very "grissely". The hostess, waitress, bus person, owner, cook(?) was the same lady. There were 6 or 7 tables and she barely ever came by. We sat for about 20min for each time she had to come to our table. But honestly, I can overlook service if the food is good. This place was so bad I almost want to decline it in my card. I will never be back. My stomach is still swirling :(
author: Rouz E.
