description: Love their chicken kabob and faloodeh. Service was pretty slow last time I went here but it's not the kind of place you go to for a quick bite.
author: Byron C.

description:
Yum.

This was my first experience with Persian cuisine, and I have to say that I'm in culinary love.

I had the kebab koobideh, half chicken and half beef upon the recommendation of my good friend, and also simply because I'm extremely indecisive when ordering food since everything usually sounds so good. The meaty kebab goodness came on a large plate with buttery, loose Basmati rice that melted into seasoned sweetness on the tongue. On the side was also a decent helping of mixed greens lathered in a light tangy dressing. Every bite of the kebab sent me into sweet oblivion, where nothing but the explosion of succulent taste in my mouth mattered, while the Basmati grains and fresh salad helped to pull everything into a mutually-complementary whole.

I don't know how this restaurant compares to other Persian establishments, but based on this single experience alone, I am now a fan of the cuisine and would recommend this to anybody who is seeking to venture outside of the familiar or is simply looking to fulfill their cravings for savory Persian flavor.

A++!
author: Amy T.

description:
Good classics, good prices by SF standards. We had the bodemjan and fessenjoon. No complaints. If you like a good sour pickle try their house pickles. It is cut up veggies in a dark, lovely vinegar brine. A bit strong on an empty stomach but good with the rest of dinner.

Solid service too.
author: Sean P.

description: Decent Persian food and ease to get to... not my number 1 choice, but I go there often.
author: Shahin P.

description:
This is a great restaurant! Wish their tables weren't glass, food slides around. But it is very classy. Food is very good!!
UPDATE: Food is still amazing, this is my family's favorite restaurant. They fixed the glass table issue! Now it's really perfect.
author: Mona K.

description: The kabobs (kubideh), doogh and chai are all very good. The pricing is reasonable in comparison to the size and quality of the dishes which are served. Although kabobs can be quite dry when ordered at other places, the kubideh was fresh and juicy - something which is not a given. Wait staff were also very friendly.
author: Sebastian F.

description:
Authentic and very good food. We've never had a bad dish here, although the kabobs and gheymeh are favorites. 

Friendly and accommodating service, child friendly.
author: Ali T.

description:
Their food has really improved recently! I used to come here and think it was alright but the last few times have been great, specially the kabobs. I don't know if they changed chefs, cooks, meat, or what, but it's way more juicy now.

Minus one star for the typical dry Iranian service.
author: Didi R.

description:
This place is pretty good.  I love the filet kabob, and the chicken is tasty too. Of course you can't beat a home cooked meal, this place offers a great alternative!  Persian Cuisine is time consuming and laborious to make at home (at least for me).  

Love their salad shirazi and the tahdig is great too.  

To the woman who claimed she got pita bread and onions.... really?  You shouldn't review what you don't know!  Oh, and don't go to a Persian restaurant and order veggie kabob - bad form!
author: Marcia K.

description:
I lost my Persian food virginity at Alborz and it went much better than the other time I lost my virginity.
Obviously I can't testify whether the food served here is authentic but this white boy thought it was damn good and that's what counts, right?
The place first of all is really cute and classy and clean-looking which is always nice. And I don't know how pathetic it is that I noticed that but they have the most awesome silverware: gorgeous glasses, star-shaped plates for the stew ... How cool is that?
The waitresses were friendly and discreet at the same time which is exactly what I want for service.
And the food was awesome. There was the lavash bread of course which was nice. And I had - per a friend's recommendation - Ghorme Sabzi which was really really nice. I made the mistake of biting into the cooked lime (careful!) but otherwise the flavors were incredibly rich. The lamb was very tender and nice. Obviously whether you like the dish is a matter of personal taste and I can't vouch over whether it was done "right" but what I ate, I enjoyed tremendously and ate it all. Same with the basmati rice.
Even the prices were quite reasonable all things considered. More than I like to spend for lunch but very reasonable for a San Francisco sit-down meal.
So, yeah, if you are in the area and want to try something different, I definitely recommend giving Alborz a shot.
author: Dorian S.

description: I've seen both good and bad reviews for this place on yelp, so I didn't know what to expect. Long story short, it was great. Joojeh kabab, ghormeh sabzi, mast o khiar... Probably the best I've had in San Francisco, or at least no less. The service was FAST. The atmosphere was was good, too. Who would have thought...
author: Armon A.

description:
I have been to this fancy classy Persian restaurant a few times.  I was quite impressed since I have been able to have authentic Persian food from actual friends and family members. I could tell the place would be good when I noticed a lot of Iranians in there.

The food from what I remember is exotic and delicious. It was such a royal treat! I am not Persian, but I love me some Persian food. And when I'm really in the mood for it this is the only place will always think
author: Lia P.

description:
I have been dining here for 6+ years without an issue and always thought the food was good... BUT I am pretty sure the management/ownership has changed recently.  The remodel look nice but the service and food are horrible!

#1, they don't bring bread unless you ask... and they serve it with onions now.. thats a big stretch from sabzi or yogurt as a starter like it was

#2, my chicken kebab showed up raw pink on the inside... no one noticed and when the waiter finally came to ask how we were, I told him and he whisked my plate away without explanation or apology.. 

#3, while waiting... my guest also noticed her chicken was raw... so we flagged the guy down and told him... he then took off with her plate, no explanation or apology.

#4, when my plate came back with re-cooked chicken it was served back on the original plate.. DISGUSTING! I explained to the waiter that when you take a dish that had undercooked chicken, you are supposed to replace the plate due to the contamination of raw chicken on the original plate.. he took the plate back as if he was pissed off at me for pointing out their own food safety problem. and by the way... my guest is still waiting for her plate... he didn't have enough sense to bring back both at the same time

#5, when my plate came back for the 2nd time...... I sat there... looking at it.. he left without a word BEFORE I could ask him for a fork and knife (since they took mine away with the original plate) and again, my guest is still waiting for her plate... idiot...

#6, after waiting for 2 minutes I flagged down the busboy for the hardware so i could take a bite..... it was cooked and dry and believe it or not.... luke warm.. seems like they tossed my raw chicken in the microwave since it cooled off so quick as was so dry......

and then about a minute later my guest gets her plate.... and he takes off again.. no sorry, nothing except "I talked to out chef".... really? who cares?

ANYWAY

#6, during this lovely 30 minute window, no one asked if we needed a drink refill... and both our glasses were totally empty...

and then we both realize we are pretty much done eating here and let the guy know we are ready for our check and want this stuff to go... and they bring us our own boxes and bags..... so much for a white linen joint that use to take your plate and pack it for you... Nope... pack it yourself like chinese take-out! 

the check arrives.... not a single apology or anything... I told the guy I was dissapointed with the service and the food and after going there for 7 years I expected a far better experience. The guys says, "well, I talked to our chef and did not charge you for your drinks".... again who cares? My drinks? Two sodas?... wow... I am so impressed... NOT

I don't plan to return... I kind of figured something was up when I noticed the staff was totally different and the nice lady who was the owner before was nowhere to be found... ohh well.. I guess I will brave the North Beach parking and start going back to Maykadeh for FAR better food and service...  THIS PLACE SUCKS!!!!!
author: Dave C.

description:
i got the bademjan khoresht with lamb and it was NOT good, not even okay! they need to train their cooks better and bring in the cook from their walnut creek location!

Update: their kabobs especially chicken w bone are great. So is their baghalipolo. 
If They start doing delivery to the neighborhood, they will see a huge jump in revenue!!
author: Ati S.

description:
Pros:
Solid Persian food in the city.  That is hard to come by.

Cons:
Service can be a little stuffy.

Fun:
Technically they are on the freeway; this stretch of Van Ness is considered part of "Highway 101."
author: Mike G.

description: The dinner we had...I hope was an outlier. The rice tasted like chemicals. The barberries were overly sweet. The staff was very nice but the kitchen is way off. If you are looking for good Persian food go to Lavash.
author: Lauren M.

description: Overpriced and subpar. The soltani meat was not fresh  - A LOT of rice but very little meat. The koobideh, and barg were both orang-y which means they used turmeric rather than saffron, to keep their cost low - that shouldn't be the case with such high prices. Won't be going there again.
author: Nasrin M.

description:
This is truly the worst Persian restaurant that we have ever been to; they have terrible food, pitiful portions, and horrible service! Our overall experience was truly disappointing!

We were a party of 4, and we each ordered their $16.00 Lamb Kabob & rice, but we were truly amazed at how shamefully small their portions were, they basically served us baby portions and we all left the restaurant very hungry! Even my 8 year old son was still hungry after his meal! 
We were served 3 very small pieces of meat and about 4 spoonfuls of rice each. The meat was so rough and poor in taste and quality that we think they lied and didn't even serve us lamb! I honestly had a hard time chewing my meat, but finally did because we were feeling so hungry, but when we left the restaurant I wished I hadn't, because I had the worst stomach cramp!

My husband who loves Persian food, was disgusted by the poor quality of their food, and even found 2 long hairs in his rice!

The server took our order but never again checked to see if we needed anything, and so we walked to the back of the restaurant and asked her if we could please pay our bill and leave! She was so rude and unattentive that we couldn't wait to leave this awful restaurant, and never again come back!

Persian people are known for their generous nature, but it is shameful that the stingy owner of this restaurant is ripping off his customers big time, and insulting their intelligence by serving them terribly poor quality food, pitiful portions, and horrible service!
author: Roya E.

description: Solid but nothing special. Dark decor. Pleasant staff! The staff is the strong point of this joint. $42 for two kabobs and two Turkish coffees is fine but a bit pricey for late lunch.
author: Ian Z.

description:
very savory Persian cuisine and friendly service with white table cloths.  we are so blessed to be in the Bay Area where restaurants like Alborz just  appear seemingly out of nowhere. the kabobs are seasoned just right here. 
here's your Persian dining tip (from my dining buddy who grew up in Tehran, Iran aka ancient Persia) for the day:
the popular way to eat the basmati rice is with a pat of butter melted on top and sprinkled with the fragrant sumac spice found at each table. 
my favorite dish here is the koobideh (ground lamb and beef with garlic, egg, tumeric, black malabar pepper and sumac).  this is marinated overnight for maximum flavor; I didn't ask but it sure taste like the meat was prepared in this manner. the koobideh is served with a roasted tomato which is also mixed into the rice. 
finish the meal with a Turkish coffee or Persian tea and you are done!
good eating!
author: Jeff W.

description:
Wow. I will never look at Persian food the same way again. 

1. Food: Amazingly delicious! The kebabs are to die for -- juicy, tender, and flavorful. The pomegranate meat sauce does not look too appealing but has a surprisingly tangy and "comforting" taste.

2. Service: Great. Our waitresses are attentive and sweet. At the time of my visit, they were especially apologetic for having burnt the rice and had to cook up another batch. To save face, they gave us some complimentary side dishes (mad props to them), which made me insanely ecstatic.

3. Price: Moderate. I ended up dropping around 20-25 bucks for having shared 3-5 courses (including appetizer salad and main courses) with two other friends.

Unfortunately I don't remember anything else about this place but once I find my pictures I will upload them. So the bottom line is... eat at this place!
author: Camie K.

description:
On the Sunday evening when we went only a few other tables in the restaurant ever filled up. There are white table cloths here but on the whole it is surprisingly unstuffy if not particularly hip. We probably stayed two hours - eating and catching up - and no one ever bothered us about it. Our water glasses were never empty and the food was great! 

When you sit down you will find a small pot filled with coarse purple-red powder. This is sumac and its flavor is at the same time sour, fruity and astringent. Try it on the rice - we liked it!

We began with the Must -o- Khiar which is a spread made with homemade yogurt, cucumbers and mint. We enjoyed it so much that we ordered another dish of it to pair with our entrees. For dinner we chose the Alborz plate for two. This platter comes with two enormous plates of rice and grilled chicken, filet mignon, and ground beef along with roasted tomatoes. The platter is definitely the way to go if you are unfamiliar with Persian cuisine and want to try a few different things.
author: Miriam W.

description: Loved this place. Sat in the window and watched the city busily pass by. Had the koobideh meal with saffron rice.  Excellent.  Cooked perfectly. My friend had the baked chicken and was praising it 2 hours after we left.  Great staff, very friendly and accommodating.
author: Joe I.

description:
The food here is absolutely delicious, especially "Shashlik".  It is always tender and tasteful.  We like to go to this place because we love their food.  However, the service could be more friendly with the smile on their faces.  

And one more thing:
CHECK YOUR BILL!!!!
The last time we've been their (it was a party of 10 and the owner lady was not there), we've been cheated for about $45. DO YOUR MATH AND CHECK YOUR BILL!  That is a reason why it is  two stars minus.
We will continue to go to this place because we like the food but we for sure will check our bills.
author: Mario L.

description:
I only give it 4 of 5 stars because of the attitude and service given. Just because I came from a long shopping excursion and not dressed in prada doesn't mean you have to look down upon me like filth??

But everything as far as food goes, absolutely yummy!!! 

I would come back. I just won't tip for the crappy and rude service.
author: Shorty '.

description:
I walked in here for a late lunch (around 2:30pm). It was completely empty, but I can assure you I've seen this place packed in the evenings. I was really craving Koobideh, and my friend that was with me had never tried it. So this place was a must as I only live a few blocks away.

We were seated immediately, and presented with the flatbread (I'm not sure what it's called) and butter. Ordered the Mast-o-Musir which was excellent. My friend and I split the Koobideh plate with 2 kabobs, rice, and a grilled tomato. EXCELLENT!

This was only my second time eating Koobideh, and it completely matched my expectations from the first time I had tried it. The portions are huge, and the one plate was enough for my friend and I. The service was wonderful, which was obviously expected since there was no one in the restaurant, but I am sure the service here is always great. The staff was really kind. I will be back!
author: Ashley D.

description: Yummy! I've been eating here for about 5 years now. Last night my friend and I went there for dinner(it was his first time dining there) and he loved it. Our favorite thing was the rice but then again everything was delicious. Hard to choose a favorite dish from the night. Two super satisfied foodie tummies.
author: Crystal G.

description: Overpriced for what you get. For a persian restaurant they are stingy with their servings and portions. The barg is dry and overcooked, joojeh was too salty and the stew is not up to par. If you want good persian, I would recommend Maykadeh or Lavash.
author: Sebastian R.

description:
I've been here many times, and while the food is really good as far as Persian goes, the prices have just gotten ridiculous. The service can be really good or really poor depending on who you get. I want to come here, but find myself avoiding it more and more. Tadik for $6 bucks, c'mon? Or was it more. 

Oh, and nice website:
Alborz Restaurants
in S.F. and Berkeley
website is under construction

Get it together man.
~Khodafez.
author: Ken L.

description:
It's too bad Iran is so, ya know, Iran, because cuisine is a major factor in choosing where I travel and apparently I love Persian food (good thing I don't know any North Korean restaurants). Perhaps it's because it's still novel; I've only had Persian food a couple of times, and both times I've felt compelled to write 5-star reviews.

Anyway, Alborz is great. The waitress was nice and didn't bat an eye when I walked in sweaty with a bike helmet and asked for a table for one.  More importantly, the food tasted great. I ordered chicken barg with zereshk polo (thanks Catriona C. for the spelling), which is a flavored rice with saffron and barberries. The rice was so flavorful it was a meal on its own, and the chicken complemented it well.

It was a bit on the pricey side, but you get what you pay for. The portions were huge, and the above came with plenty of flatbread, a side of spiced onions, and a heap of tangy yogurt sauce. If you're not a glutton like me, you'll have a good sized lunch to bring home.
author: Adam B.

description:
smelly place, but we really liked the main dishes ( we ordered koobideh and Barg).

for appetizer we ordered Tahdig and it wasn't fresh at all, probably for the last day or so but Kashkobademjan was great.
author: Sara K.

description: Very bad Persian food. there are better Persian restaurant with authentic Persian food.I would not recommend this place
author: Siroos H.

description: Horrible chicken barg...beef was ok.  Overpriced for quality and portions.  Poor presentation.
author: Bat M.

description:
Hands down the BEST koobideh in town! I did not care for the Barg or the Shishlick. But who cares about those...the koobideh will rock your world! Oh, and the service was also good.

Can't wait to go back for more koobideh :)
author: Nazanin A.

description: Food was scrumptious, though yes, I second all the other reviews that mention how it's a tad overpriced. The yogurt that comes before you order is really really good. Tastes nothing like the sugary crap that comes out of Yoplait cows. This stuff was more like whole milk fattiness plus sour cream tang. Delicious with the warm pitas they give you. There was also a side plate of carmelized onions, o hullo. Once you sprinkle on some pretty sumac, the lemony blast makes it almost a meal in itself. This would be one of those moments where you probably want to stop guzzling the "free" bread and wait on your entree. I got the chicken koobideh (chicken kebabs), which come with saffron'd rice. Really nicely done chicken! I also tried some of my friend's fesanjan (chicken in pomegranate walnut sauce). WOWEE, I wanted another platter of rice to suck up the sauces.
author: Kevin L.

description: Are you serious??? One hour to get the order to the table??? I was hungry one hour ago, but now I'm sick?? You guys need more people to handle this kind of restaurant. Please don't go there, but if you want to just call two hours ahead and let them know you're coming????
author: tarik i.

description:
Restaurant.com shoppers, beware.

I've had a restaurant.com gift certificate for a while now, but prior to heading over, decided to check out the reviews.  The one from 2/22 caught my eye, which detailed how the restaurant was refusing to honor the certificates despite restaurant.com's insistence that they were active.  I decided to call and ask, the hostess said that her boss has ordered the staff not to accept any gift certificates since they cancelled their contract "a few months ago".  The boss, of course, wasn't available for an explanation.

Seems pretty shady and entirely dishonest, won't give them any business even if the food is ok.
author: Corey L.

description: I am Persian, and this is a grade-A spot. The koobideh & soltani dishes are my favorite: the meat is juicy without being greasy, and always extremely flavorful.  The rice is very aromatic, and the appetizers are all great. Generous portions, friendly wait staff, lovely decor, and scrumptious food: Alborz has it all.
author: Mithra H.

description:
My go to Persian restaurant of choice in SF. I get the craving and nip over to get my 'fix'! 

Please note: The whole point of Persian food is the meat, so don't waste your time to come here to eat shrimp or vegetables - you will be missing out! Kabab Koobideh is my favorite - flavorful, succulent - yum, yum, yum! We usually go for one of the more interesting rices such as the Shrini Polo or that other one with dill and beans. The Koobideh serving size is huge, so I usually share or end up with a doggie bag.

I've only tried a few of the appetizers - the yogurt with cucumber, yogurt with garlic, houmous and the Kashk Badamjan. They are fairly good, the yogurts are very garlicy, but the Kashk Bademjan is amazing.

I never have space for dessert, but keep eyeing up the Faloodeh, which is another favorite of mine, and the Persian ice cream!
author: Writer G.

description:
I ordered the abalo polo ; it came on a bed of sweet tasting rice and it was pretty good. 
Been here once and i'd go back again.
decor: white table cloth, nice and polite service.
Next time, I'll try the Zereshk Polo or filet mignon kabob.

Sorry SF, but IMHO So. Cal. has much better Persian food, specifically, you want to cruise over to Darya , in the city of Orange.
Quality everything food and service.  
Only Raffi's in Glendale has better rice, but they claim to be Persian and Armenian.
author: Bert K.

description:
Not so much.

I'll start with first impressions.  I went on an off night (a Tuesday).  It was totally empty, really bright and all the tables were white-clothed.  Now, don't get me wrong.  White table clothes aren't bad all the time, but it just didn't match the rest of the atmosphere.  And really bright lights with lots of windows on Van Ness is not the least bit mood-setting.

Ok, on to the one good thing - the yogurt and cucumber dip (yum).  My friend explained to me that the onions/bread thing (sorry that's not PC, I don't know what the appetizer is called) was supposed to make you salivate since the rest of the food would be dry.  Well, about that, he was right.  But it wasn't dry in an "authentic" way, just in a bland, not good at all way.

Maybe you'll have better luck, but if you're looking for great Persian flavors, I just don't think you'll find them here.
author: Gretchen S.

description: I love this restaurant.  Today was the second time I've been there for lunch.  Yummy!  First, I had Kookoo Sabzi, baked finely chopped herbs mixed with egg and walnuts.  Then I had a cup of their Asah Reshteh, Persian noodle soup with fresh herbs, pinto beans, and topped with whey and fried onions.  My friend always has their Shish Kabob--a skewer of fillet mignon, onions, and bell peppers.  We sat in the corner window seat and thoroughly enjoyed our meal and glasses of Merlot.  The wait staff is welcoming and helpful.  I can hardly wait to go back and try more 'new to me' dishes.
author: Diane L.

description: DELICIOUS FOOD, I DREAM ABOUT THE FOOD HERE! Lovely staff and parking is usually a breeze within 1 block. excellent quality food and a great place for special occasions or just to grab a bite. LOVES IT!
author: Rolf S.

description:
I came for dinner here and had a few items (as usual)

We started with the prawn appetizer and the paneer sabzi (the herbs with walnuts and feta)

The prawns were good--I really liked the paneer but felt like the portion was pretty skimpy.  I would totally have that again, but would prefer a larger portion--especially since there were three of us, they didn't make any mention that we should order more than one order.  Boo.

For my meal I had the combo Koobideh (one chicken and one beef)--the koobideh was probably my favorite thing I ate--it was so flavorful and good.  It's a little visually unappealing, but it was really tasty.

I didn't get a chance to eat dessert because i was too full from my main dish, but I don't even think the meal needed that added touch.  

I think the prices are a little spendy, but not too out of control.  

I'm sure I will return here at some point.  I liked the food but next time I won't be sharing my paneer sabzi!
author: Lu E.

description:
A Persian friend told me that I would probably like this place because I am not Persian and didn't grow up eating Persian food. She recommended better place where Persians would actually prefer.

However, I still decided to come here for our anniversary dinner with my beau. Place is in busy area in Van ness. Came in and was seated right away. I noticed that there was only one waitress who was also the hostess. Great the place has people few of them and there was only one person there. I was worried. Maybe should have walked out. But I was glad that I didn't! The food came to be a surprise. I had the appetizer which included samples of all the appetizer. I was delighted. I was happy. Immediately, my doubts were gone. Then for the main entree, I've ordered the combination shish kabobs. The rice with the saffron was great. I was out of words. I hate that my friend was right. That she said that I was going to like it. I did indeed like it. It was very delicious! I did not have enough room for the dessert. Though I came in with doubts, I left satisfied even with to go. The portions were ample. I was glad that I came here. Worth the try!

Perhaps I would have more experience with Persian food but this place was right to begin with.
author: J C.

description:
My dad and I being Iranian, we eat a lot of Persian food. He had been here before with a date and loved it, so he deided to bring me here. I loved it too! The starter of pita with mastokhiar, butter, and onion was delicious, and I spent about half of the space in my small stomach eating it--I just couldn't keep my hands away for more than 30 seconds. 

Our entrée was delivered quickly (10-15 minutes). We shared the Alborz Plat For Two, cooked medium-well. The meat was cooked perfectly, and the rice was delicious. The doogh was incredibly thirst-quenching and the tea had the perfect amount of flavor (sort of saffony). I have to say that this is one of, if not the, best Persian restaurants that I've had the pleasure of dining at. 

Aside from the food, the service was quick and friendly, and the lady who greeted us spoke to my dad in Farsi without thinking twice. When she seated us, I mentioned that I didn't speak Farsi and she said "I know, I could tell when I first said hello." Very sharp!
author: Arman D.

description:
OOOOOMMMMGEEEEE
My cousin and I were craving persian food and we never tried this place before but we figured we give it a shot....it was heaven on earth!!
THE FOOD IS AMAZING...get the 2 person platter, combination appetizer, and the combo dessert...the service was excellent and the waiters gave excellent suggestions.

It has been a long time since I was extremely happy with the way my food taste. If you have a chance go check this place out they deserve the business.
author: Eric S.

description: Al Borz is my "go to" Persian restaurant in the City.  Nice kebabs and traditional dishes.  They have a large room that faces Van Ness and you feel comfortable there.  Recently I left behind a pair of expensive sunglasses.  In most places, the waiter would have swiped it into their own personal collection but not here.  After a few searches in different boxes, my sunglasses were returned in original condition.  This is the type of the place you want to be a regular at.
author: Laurence H.

description: The fillet of lamb was delicious! Service was also great. No complaints. Not the best place ever but certainly not the worst.
author: Leanne S.

description:
Okay, if you like Iranian, Turkish, Georgian food or if you simply can't live without meat, this place is for you! Seriously, meat is amazing here. We were group of 8 and ordered different kinds of main meal. Everyone liked their food. Plus, it is served with huge portion of rice.

If you want to try persian food, it is one of the best places in San Francisco to do it. Cooked with love by people who know what real persian food should taste like.

I could say "save some room for desert", but I won't. Deserts were a bit of disappointment. I love baklava and know how the proper baklava tastes. The one I tried at Alborz wasn't proper. I wasn't surprised, though. My experience shows, that the best baklava is served only in Turkey.

The second negative thing (after deserts) was check. It was hand written and hard to read, but the staff was very helpful.
author: Igor T.

description: The fillet of lamb is so tender and is just full of flavor in your mouth, it's almost sublime. Service is prompt, ambiance is not bad. I gotta say that their rose water saffron ice cream is a must try. It has a clean taste, not disgustingly sweet, just pure bliss for the palate.
author: Kara Y.

description:
On Saturday, we attended a party here. I read the reviews from other Yelpers and I knew we were going to have a great meal here. I was right the food here was delicious. We started with the pita, yogurt, hummus and assortment of smoked fishes, Olivier salad, and more. 

We had two version of the rice - jewelled and regular. A huge assortment of lamb chops, chicken bargs and beef kabobs. 

The decor was very nice and plenty of natual light. The location is right on the corner of Van Ness and Sutter.

The parking a bit crazy. We decided to park at Polk Bush Parking and walk a few block before and after dinner.
author: Rose F.

description:
If you have a coupon for the place-- they dont honor it!!! Call before you go to make sure they take online coupons!

I thought the food was very good but pricey for what you are getting.  The issue was when we but when we produced a coupon (our friends bought one of those coupon books which incl 20% off Alborz) they would not honor it and would not even give us free drinks or dessert.  I thought the food was good but they did not encourage us to return and the prices were high....
author: Judy G.

description: well worth the visit. the baked chicken khoresht (shirin polo) is phenomenal. attentive and very friendly service.
author: RA F.

description:
Great food overall, very reasonably priced, nice ambiance, but mediocre service.

Let me first disclaim that my girlfriend is Persian. 100%. FOB (fresh off the boat). We eat delicious homemade Persian food regularly. 

The Kebab here is great. Also, they have several yummy horeshts. Saladi Shirazi (Salad of Shiraz) is excellent as well. Some of their lamb dishes left a bit to be desired (I've had better lamb prepared at home). They sometimes have two different types of doug (yogurt drink), but will only bring the good one if you're Persian and ask for it. The carbonated one is OK, but I prefer the homemade style doug. 

Overall, this spot is a great bet to have delicious Persian food! Don't expect miracles from the the wait staff, and you'll be sure to have a good time.
author: Matthew J M.

description: I visit Alborz restaurant ones a month, they have best kababs ever. I mostly go there in lunch time in midweek,cause price more reasonable and cheap from 11 am to 3pm. Relaxing interior, nice and clean and good service. Portion is great.Love Zaresht polo with Kobideh:)
author: Abraham F.

description:
While reviews here on Yelp seem to be mixed for the place, we were nothing but thoroughly impressed.

Let's start from the top with the food: excellent. We came in here starving and were so happy to see the huge portions. One dish and a humus was enough to keep us both full, and the complimentary yogurt and peta to top it off were awesome. Rice was good, meat was good, yogurt was good, peta was good, and the humus was amazing. Oolala, a winning food combination.

The service here was also good. The waiter didn't seem as engaged as he could have been, but was attentive to us and rapidly catered to all our requests. The location itself is also very nice, with a fancy edge that puts it over the top.

Overall, the place gets our highest mark. We will surely be back someday.
author: Sami R.

description: I absolutely LOVE this place, it is the best persian food I've ever had besides what my family makes. I have never had a bad meal here and I've been coming for about 5 years now. I also love the wait staff, they are all friendly and prompt. A must-try in SF if you are a fan of middle eastern food!
author: Chloe A.

description:
My friend and I had a bad experience at this restaurant. We went in with a restaurant.com coupon and the waitress said they no longer accept them. So I basically wasted my money on a worthless gift certificate. After complaining to the waitress they offered us a free appetizer, but this was worth far less than the $25 value of the certificate.  I went online afterward and Alborz is still listed on restaurant.com! This seems like false advertising to me and isn't right.

That being said, the appetizer sampler and beef koobideh were tasty, but I've been to Persian restaurants that were better and less expensive.
author: Kevin M.

description:
Before converting to pescatarianism, I loved me some fesunjoon. No more shall I sample that amazing pomegranate and walnut sauce, unless it is draped coquettishly over a slice of eggplant, or something. Going to Alborz for my birthday was a little like torturing myself, at least with anticipation. What will I have? Will there be anything? That's OK, I can eat hummus!

I didn't have to worry. We shared the combination plate (beef stuffed dolmas (not for me), eggplant dip, a crazy egg & walnut 'dip' (it looked more like a lump of coal - it tasted good but boy did it look odd on the plate), and obligatory feta, walnuts & fresh herbs). For my main, I had the maygoo (try not to snigger, if you are as ignorant as me when you order it) - tiger prawn kebabs with rice. I had mine with zereshk polo - basically barberries and saffron rice. The rice really blew me away - so much that I ate enough to keep digesting through til lunch the next day. The dried barberries were sharp and really through some sparkle into the meal. Everyone needs some sparkle in their life, right?

Finally, I had a piece of baklava, with a candle in it. So sweet!  Literally and metaphorically. My friends feasted on beef kebabs and Caesar salad - and not one unhappy person at the table. Service was really nice and friendly, and didn't mind us turning up less than an hour before closing. No rushing us out the door either.
author: Catriona C.

description: Waitress was very kind and attentive, sorry to hear the other experiences but my experience was great! the melt off the bone lamb shank was absolutely delicious. I highly recommend trying it out. (skip the chicken) go for the beef or lamb!
author: Tiff W.

description:
What happened to this place? 

The food is mediocre at best. The chicken skewers were not marinated at all and were really overcooked. 

The waitress was rude and overcharged us too!
author: Leo S.

description: I've been wanting to try Alborz Persian Cuisine restaurant for too long of a time. Tonight a small group of us walked in with thankfully not a wait time at all. Alborz is an unsung gem of a restaurant. Despite the location, the busy Polk Gulch/Pac Heights Van Ness corridor, the restaurant was like a tranquil little oasis, with a nice view of the busy world outside. The menu selection was great; it had a variety of items that I like from other Middle Eastern restaurants. The koobideh and eggplant puree ended up being my favorites, and are enough to bring me back for a follow-up visit. In the end, we ate and drank well with a reasonable bill at the end.
author: Jen A.

description:
How did this place get Four stars?   I mean sure, it has good service, even up to very good at times.   If you are having some sort of family or business deal going on they can provide an mound og good food.\

But as for top of the line Persian cuisine I don't really rate Alborz as top of the  heap.  The last three time I have eaten at Alborz they have served your basic good restaurant Persian food.  But don't ask for your tadiq here as they don't serve it in a manner that befits a good rice crust.  The rest of the rice from the pot is your standard delicious basmati rice.

The stews are good.
The khoobideh is unreliable.  Sometimes perfect, sometimes less than desirable..

It's not a bad place mind you, but like their web site that has been forever unfinished (http://www.alborzrestaurants.com)  just not four stars worth.  So I have not felt any desire to return here in while.   

Maybe it's time to go back again and give them another shot, and another review.  Till then Alborz get a solid three stars from me.
author: Chris R.

description: Excellent food. The atmosphere is a little quite, but it was very nice. The food was wonderful. Not as good as Grandma's, but it was up there. Very Cheap!! $50 for two HUGE entrees and an appetizer, plus bread and onions.
author: L S.

description: The food here is terrible! The ground beef kabobs had absolutely zero flavor. I was dying for some ketchup or hot sauce -- anything to make them barely edible. My dinner here was one of the worst meals I've had in a restaurant in a long, long time! (Note: This refers to a meal I had about a year and a few months ago)
author: Olivia P.

description:
Went here for dinner.  Service was attentive.  Food was okay.  We had the Alborz dinenr for two, and were slightly underwhelmed.  Nothing stood out, and nothing was spectacular.  

Dolmas were tasty, but 7$ for 3 pieces that lacked ground beef seemed a bit stiff.  The Alborz dinner was 35$ and comes with three skewers, one of chicken, of filet mignon, and ground beef.  Definitely filling, but it lacks a certain oomph.

Money is tight right now.  I don't like to eat out if I can save money eating at home.  So when a dinner costs 50+ dollars, I kind of want it to be special, and to be memorable, at least something that satisfies the taste buds.

It's not a bad place for food, but if I were to go here again, I think I will go with their combination or their special.  I saw other people ordering it, and it came out on a giant plate iwth rice, sald, and meat.
author: Tangerine L.

description: Food was ok. They do win the "Math is Hard" award for the bill. When asked to give each table it's own check they instead divided the total check by 3.  Thanks.
author: Toben G.

description: Very cute place - really nice service, and great food.  I had the tabbouleh and the Barg (filet kebab), and they were both fantastic.  The Barg was incredibly tender and flavorful - would definitely get it again!
author: Susan W.

description:
My bf recommended this place as great not heavy Persian food. After not eating it for 5 years, I trusted his advice and came. Unfortunately I have no recollection as to the names of the dishes that I ordered, but we did order the combination appetizer which came with a gamut of options, the eggplant being the best.  Then we had an appetizer which was basically fried/hardened rice with a sauce of your choice. This was the best dish and only around $7.  The kabobs are huuuuge, and if you have a big appetite then order two. I had one, and took four pieces home. I like their rice as well.  

The only annoying thing is the shared bathroom down the hall in which you need a key. I swear the girl that took the ladies room key was in there FOREVER and all I wanted to do was wash my hands.  Thankfully the host gave me their secret key.
author: Natalie S.

description:
After a Sunday afternoon of skating, warming up with some afternoon drinks it was time to eat a warm and hearty meal. My boyfriend's brother got a shout-out for this place, so off we went me, my daughter, my boyfriend, his brother and parents. 

Housed on the corner of Sutter and Van Ness, Alborz is quaint and simple. There is a very small bar area, where the second and third tier of the restaurant is for the general eatery. The bathrooms are apparently situated in a Matrix-like hallway. The Architect will be waiting for you providing you have the keys. And the restaurant definitely accommodates parties over six, so you know you're in good hands. 

My boyfriend's dad ordered the Combination Platter for our appetizer. The platter includes dolma (beef with herbs, rice and lentils wrapped in grape leaves), kashk bademjan (roasted eggplant), cucumbers, tomatoes, herbs, feta cheese and Greek olives. We were brought two baskets of flat pita bread and cucumber yogurt dips with onions on the side. Everything was good and definitely felt fresh to eat.

For dinner, I had the soup which was just so good and looked like a lot but left me content but not full. I ordered for my entree the Joojeh with Bone, which was okay, the cornish hen was slightly dry and I secretly envied my boyfriend's order of the Joojeh, which was just the chicken but marinated in lime and saffron. The entire meal was definitely filling. But I agree with the other reviewers, something was missing. 

Although the service was decent, I can't put my finger on what was off with the place. Nonetheless, we all enjoyed a good meal in good company.
author: Jamie L.

description:
We arrived late for dinner here and they politely requested we order because the kitchen was closing soon.  I admit Persian food is a bit not bland, but not spicy hot enough for me.  The halal lamb dish I ordered was good, but not amazing.  A crazy homeless man attempted to enter the restaurant to sell flowers and got to our table where the person I was with did get a flower, but then the buser rudely kicked the guy out.  Sure, he smelled, but I got a flower and was happy and like helping the homeless when, where, and how possible.  

In sum, this place is good enough, but I'll more likely to go out for Pakistani to get my halal fix.
author: Cara J.

description: Quick tip for weeknight dining: Restaurant open til 10:00. Take-out only after 9 or 9:30... call ahead to be sure.
author: Sara G.

description: Came here for lunch to celebrate a friend's birthday. Not cheap but excellent food and worth each penny. The chicken kaboob was mouth watering! My friend is half persian and this is her fave place. Yum!
author: Avi B.

description: Been to this place twice, once for take-out once dining in. I've never seen it packed which is fine by me, but I tend to eat early to avoid crowds in the city.  Both times I've ordered the koobideh because, well, I love koobideh and I can never seem to get it right when I try to make it myself.  All the different jeweled rices are lovely.  Our waitress was lovely; we had a nice conversation with her.  I think this would be a great date place.  It has intimate, romantic lighting and lighting.  Parking was tricky but it's easy to get to on MUNI or BART so I would suggest that.
author: Summer T.

description:
I've visited all the Persian joints in the city and Marin and several in the East Bay. I like this Alborz the best.

Still, it leaves a ton to be desired.

I went there with some white friends last night, and they loved the food, but come on Haji, hire another waitress. That poor women was serving a packed house on a Friday night all by her lonesome.

No wonder a couple of our items got forgotten. 

The food was good, and for those of you uninitiated in Persian dining, order your meal family style. It just makes more sense, and you have the chance to try a few different items.

I really like that this Alborz is in a decently convenient location.

The shared bathroom with the Village Pizzeria is kind of a turn off, but it reminds you that this ain't fine dining. It's not supposed to be.
author: Jason R.

description:
The food is excellent! This is a quiet little place with white tablecloths, but isn't stuffy. 

The mint cuc yogurt is great as is the beef and filet combo. Very very filling food. Baklava is quite good without being overly sweet.
author: Erin J.

description:
I just had dinner at this pac heights restaurant in SF with some family members.  we ordered kobideh and sultani kebobs, which were pretty good. the service was friendly and the food came out really quickly. the restaurant was clean and not too long of a wait...

...so why the one star?  because once i got the bill for dinner, the waitress included the tip automatically...and there were only 4 of us...  

it was strange.  I know about the 5% SF, but she included the tip into the bill and and just wrote it onto the receipt herself.  I really have never had this experience. 

i don't know if i gave the 'i don't tip' vibe, but i actually tip...for the record. 

I was actually happy throughout the dinner, but this little thing just was so strange, I had to drop the 1 star!
author: Roy N.

description: I stop by Alborz for lunch at times. Great kabobs, i would stick with the lamb and beef combos and appetizers. Great service. Clean and as far as Persian food go in SF a great choice at reasonable prices.
author: vahid r.

description:
I pretty much love all Persian cuisine and it's been hard to find in the city.

This place is pretty darn delicious and somewhat close to where I live. Great prices for how nice it is too.
author: Lynsey C.

description:
Since moving to the bay area I've been missing my mom's home cooked meals so badly! Luckily one night when I was in the city friends suggested we go to Alborz to pick up some dinner. 

Usually when you walk into a Iranian restaurant you are expecting run of the mill decor (for a chelo kababi restaurant) and typical music playing.  

The decor was there, slightly beat up but there, and you could hardly hear the music.  Not that I would normally care, but the restaurant was near empty (and quiet) except for a group of 10 in the corner and another couple in the other corner. Would have felt more welcoming if there was more noise?

Ok to food. Honestly it was all good I have no complaints. Actually I had to give an extra star for the fact they served zaboon as an appetizer on a weeknight! I was so excited seeing it on the menu. We ordered it and it was delicious. Since we were about 5 people we decided to do family style which worked out great, bc Iranian restaurants always bring out way too much rice. We ordered a number of things but the one thing I liked off the menu was the option to three types of kabab for sharing with rice. Iranian food at home is family style but for some reasons at restaurants it isn't served as family style, although many of the American restaurants have people who want to treat it that way. Which is ok but the restaurants need to catch up and understand this! So when it comes to wanting to do family style, I've normally seen a "soltani" option where they give you two types of kabab, uniquely but Alborz offered another dish that gave three kababs, obviously understanding people like to do family style. I like that, made life easier choosing things to eat. 

I took two points off because the waiter wasn't good. It was hard to get his attention, and he acted like he didn't understand my Farsi.  WTF? I asked him his recommendation on a couple of things, usually waiters give you their opinion and reasons why he just sorta pointed and said "this one" but no explanation. Now I'm not stupid I grew up with Iranian food, so I just shrugged him off and made a decision off of what I knew, but what if someone who's never has Iranian food comes in and he treats them like that? They'll be so confused on what to do!

All in all good food, check it out, but don't expect much with service.
author: Sunny D.

description:
Came here for dinner on a Monday evening.  The "Persian mommy" as my dining partner called her was the very nice hostess/server.

He ordered the special, which was shish kabob w/ salad and rice, i got one of the stews (lean cubes of beef, lentils, fried eggplant, in a tomato-y sauce), the 2nd one listed under "house specialties."

The stew was very flavorful, the beef really tender, and just wonderful eaten w/ the fragrant basmati rice.  His kabob was also tender and well-seasoned.

Portions are very reasonable and the place is fairly quiet, though that may be because there were only a few tables occupied.

I definitely intend on coming back here to try more of their options!

FYI: the bathroom is located outside of the restaurant, shared w/ a couple other establishments in the building. just pick up the proper key at the hostess table and head out the side door.
author: Naoko M.

description:
This place is good if you like meat. I like the food here, it's more of a formal restaurant feel. But I am lacking a wider choice of vegetables. 
Friendly service.
author: Alexandra D.

description:
This is a quick review.  Persian food in general is amazing.  Alborz does some things good, others not as good.  To start, like others stated, it doesn't come close to home cooked Persian food.  My girlfriends mom makes amazing Persian food.  
    The Alborz in Berkeley is better than the San Francisco location.  The rice seemed fresher.  I generally get kabob when I come here, and the chicken, filet mignon and koobideh (ground meat) are all good.  Most other stuff on the menu my gf's mom makes better so I don't mess with it.  But the chicken fesinjoon was pretty good.  Do yourself a  favor and give Persian food a try if you've not done so yet.  And get a Dugh, the yogurt drink
author: Chris R.

description:
As much as I've enjoyed reading all the honkey reviews of their introductions to Persian food, I have a piece of advice, you don't go to Persian restaurants for SHRIMP COCKTAIL. That's GROSS.

Anyway - and those who say Maykedeh is better probably just had a good night at Maykedeh because I'd take Alborz over that place any day.  

Now that I live in LA - I miss the convenience of Alborz. Even though I supposedly live in the Tehrangeles vicinity, I love the uncomfortable silence and awkwardness of the wait staff.  The super eager or barely there attention.  It's good.  Adds some culture. 

Koobideh - always succulent - so juicy. Hot steamy light fluffy rice.  
Zehreshk - a little sweet for my taste but I love Zehreshk so too bad.
Fesenjon - Delicious w/ chicken. Think they offer lamb too but I don't eat lamb because it smells like wet hay under the weight of 10 sheep.

And yes the wait staff can be all over you. They're persian. They're fuckin pushy.  That's the way it is.
author: Jerkey J.

description:
After a magical Nutcracker at the Opera House a few days before Christmas, my family and I decided to check out Alborz. At first I was a little skeptical due to the fact that we were the only customers. However, soon enough, big parties and a few couples started to fill the restaurant. The owner was very friendly and had a smile on always. I ordered chicken, my mom ordered the koobideh, and my dad - the salmon. The pita bread and onions were very interesting and the salad was nice and light but a little small, portion wise. The food came out soon and we ate our meals happily. There was something missing with the food, however. I can't put my finger on it, but I felt like it was lacking that certain spice to make all the ingredients come together and blend perfectly. The dinner experience all together was pleasant. I just didn't like how the bathroom was shared with other restaurants down a creepy hallway. 

Food: 4
Service: 5
Ambiance: 3.5
author: Rachel M.

description:
Went here w/my family a few weeks back and had a great time. feel likes a "typical" persian restaurant with a very laid back, informal, friendly service.

bargh, soltani, the eggplant appetizer which i can't seem to recall (don't feel like looking up) was good and didn't sit in your stomach which "restaurant kabob" tends to do.
author: sam y.

description:
I went here awhile ago and keep forgetting to write my review of this place.  It's a neighborhood restaurant, so my sweetie and I decided to go here for lunch one day.

We both ordered from the charbroiled kabobs.  I had the chicken koobideh and he had the filet of lamb.  The chicken is AMAZING!!!  We liked the lamb too.  My date ordered the chicken koobideh on top of his lamb, because he loved it so much.

I liked the set up of their plates.  Basmati rice and roasted tomoatoes.  Perfect combo.

The restaurant is quiet and open, with white table cloths.  It was a bit chilly inside and the service was a bit on the slower side, but we enjoyed ourselves.  Getting to the bathroom is  bit of a bizarre task and it isn't very warm either:)

We will definitely be back and recommend trying this place if you want to get a taste of Persian food.  MmmMMm...
author: Kat M.

description:
Craving Koobideh!

I've had several great lunches here. I usually get the koobideh (minced meat kabab) meal which comes with basmati rice. The food is rich with spices and flavor. $10-12 for lunch is bit steep, but the portions are large enough that I share with someone else.

Would give this place 5-stars, but it's a little pricey.
author: Mike L.

description:
Alborz translates to "bad" in Farsi. 

We came in here a couple weeks ago because it was close to my buddy's work.

It was practically empty, but for a reason unknown to us at the time.

First off, if you are Iranian or of Persian decent, the food outside is never as good as Maman - Bozorg so it is difficult to make comparisons. 

With Alborz, you have no comparison simply because the food and service are awful.

Let's go through a check-list:

1. Service: You would expect a server to be a little more attentive when only six people are in the entire restaurant, including yourself. 

No, "how's the food?" or "would you like a refill?" ever graced us


2. Food: Old. The tah dig served felt like it has been frozen and then ultimately de-frosted. How can one be so sure?

Well, true tahdig is crispy, and easily comes off the fork when pressing slightly on it. The tahdig at Alborz felt like it made or iron ore. No knife would have qualified in cutting it to pieces. 

Fesenjoon: Did not taste fresh. Did not want to send it back in fear of retribution. 

Chicken and beef: Not cooked well. One was overcooked, and the other under. In fairness, the pita bread and the rice were good, but you don't spend $20 a plate to find that out.

3. Bill: Overcharged in the drinks category by a non-existent server. Always fun when a restaurant adds insult to injury.

4. Management: I have read a few reviews in regards to the Restaurant.com vouchers people purchased but were not able to use. Not surprised. They probably realized that it was a bad decision when four of their five customers have coupons, and they weren't hitting their monthly quotas. I sympathize with the people who paid money for the certificates, and then should at the very least be reimbursed.

5. Conclusion: Stay the hell away.

The tab runs up quickly (in our instance over $100) and you getting no-value add for the money spent. A suggestion in general: 

The Bay area's Persian restaurants have taken mediocrity to unfathomable heights. Consistently, the food is not up to par with some of its SoCal counterparts and should be avoided.

If you have a Maman - Bozorg (Grandma) who cooks insanely delicious, flavorful, fresh, and ample servings of Iranian food, please kiss her for me on the cheek and let's start eating.

For Alborz, I truly hope that they learn from their mistakes and managerial ineptitude, and stop making Persians look bad in the process. 

DB
author: Dave B.

description:
Alborz is hands down one of my favorite restaurants in the city and it's a plus that I live just a block away. My husband is Persian and his family cooks authentic Persian food all the time. Alborz measure up great with my Mother-in-laws home cooked meals and sometime even surpasses them. 

We celebrated my husband's birthday with our friends and had a full meal and it ended up being about $35 per person. The portions are rich and designed to enjoy family style. I can see how it can be difficult to order for someone that has little experience with Persian food however that is the case for most ethnic restaurants and it's a learning experience.

I look forward to my take-out meal tonight for Valentines Day!
author: Mariell R.

description:
I like tasty, fresh food but I value a quiet restaurant above all else. This is, for my money, the only restaurant in town that has space and a sense of calm while eating. A great place to go if you want to have a conversation without having to lean in to hear your dining companion.

That said--the food is always mouthwateringly delicious. Especially the Chicken in Pomegranate/Walnut sauce. The eggplant appetizer is mouth watering and their home made pita bread is perfect.

I've been there almost 10 times now in the last 2 years.

The service is friendly and considerate.
author: mike t.

description:
WARNING... DISHONEST MANAGEMENT... FRAUD... BAIT AND SWITCH

As a Persian Colleague in the East Bay had referred me to Alborz in Walnut Creek and Fremont, I was excited to try the one in San Francisco. Now I'm not sure if they're even related. I felt lucky to have found a restaurant.com voucher for $50 worth of food for $25. When we arrived for our reservation, the hostess informed us after we were seated that they did not accept the Restaurant.com vouchers anymore and that for 7 months they have been requesting that their name be taken off the website. They told us THEY were victims of fraud. We decided to order a little less food and try the restaurant just the same. The hostess was nice enough to comp us an appetizer of tabouleh salad.

On returning home we found that Alborz still offered vouchers on restaurant.com. We called restaurant.com and they informed us that the management had NOT made any request to remove their name from the voucher service and that we were the third party to complain about Alborz not honoring the vouchers. Apparently restaurant.com is legally bound to keep the contract with Alborz until there are 4 complaints filed. I was very disappointed at the dishonesty and the bait and switch technique used to lure people to their restaurant.

NOW FOR THE ACTUAL REVIEW
I could not in good conscience give such a restaurant more than one star for their lack of ethics. If not for that incident, I'd give a solid 3 stars.

FOOD... Three Stars, I've eaten some really fantastic Persian food... this is not tops, but it was decent, much more decent than other reviewers have stated. The lavash bread was served with onions and butter but without the customary herbs (mint, italian parsley, etc) which I thought was a little strange. 

The rice served with the main courses was very good... nothing to complain about. The kabobs quality of meat was delicious and tender; I've seen larger pieces of meat, of course, but they were not inordinately small and neither of us could finish the meal it was so large, and we like to eat, so no complaints on the portion. Fesenjoon was delicious... chicken in a walnut and pomegranate sauce. A solid 3 stars

DECOR&PRESENTATION- not dingy as others may have complained, but definately ready for a facelift. I would not recommend based on decor and would not recommend for a first date. The presentation of the food was not present but nothing was spilled either, just no effort to be special or beautiful.

PRICE- Appetizers and side salads were $7-12, most entrees were $12-$25, so I'd say the place was moderately priced, unlike some of the other reviews, I'd say it's probably average for a sit-down Persian Restaurant. Not a great value, but not astronomical.

SERVICE- Other than the blatant dishonesty described above, the service was fine. We were greeted and seated immediately. The staff were pleasant. We were not left unattended, no one hovered over the table obnoxiously, average, straight-forward service.
author: J B.

description:
If you ever wonder why grown Iranian dudes never move out of their parents' houses, it's because of the food. There's no Persian food quite as good as your mom's or grandma's. Luckily, they taught me the cuisine and I could make it for myself, but it's time consuming and requires lots of specialty ingredients.


 So even though we could cook for ourselves, my Iranian friends and I (and one farangi aka gringo) felt like saving time one night and hit up Alborz for dinner.


 Now the menu and service at just about any Persian restaurant in the world is going to be about the same: A selection of chelokababs and stews, some de rigeur appetizers, and maybe some rice dishes. So the only real point of competition, besides price, is in the quality of both the dishes and the ingredients used.


 Alborz largely succeeds. We started with an order of mast-o-khiar (yogurt with cucumbers) to dip our lavash flatbread in, and it was good. Rich in consistency, not runny, and stuck to the bread. We added on an order of mast-o-museer and were impressed. Museer is elephant garlic, a hard-to-find relative of the shallot and the leek, and a lot of places cheap out and use either shallots or very little of the real thing. Not these guys - so we knew we'd be in for a treat.


 Our next appetizer arrived: tahdig (the crunchy crust from the bottom of a pot of rice) covered in ghormeh sabzi (a spinach and fenugreek stew with red beans). The beans were unfortunately canned, so we had a bit of apprehension before we got to the main course


 And we weren't disappointed. The kababs were fantastic, and we all shared skewers of the barg (filet mignon), koobideh (ground beef) and joojeh (boneless chicken) and enjoyed every bit. But the real standout part was the rice. The chelo in chelokabab stands for the rice, and it's an integral part of the meal - some might even say the star. Preparing basmati rice in the Iranian fashion is a painstaking process, and many steps are often omitted in the restaurant biz because of the volume and turnover involved. Alborz did not skimp. The rice is fragrant, perfectly cooked, and appropriately garnished with a good amount of saffron - another area where many restaurants would cheap out.


 And while we weren't decked out in black leather and Drakkar, we decided to fully PerZiAn out and capped off our gutbusting dinner with tea and dessert. The darjeeling tea, laced with a bit of cardamom, came in large glasses (we don't do cups in the Axis of Evil) and with quality firm sugar cubes. The baklava was good, with a decent amount of pistachio. However, the zulubia and bamieh - the closest way to describe them would be honey-dipped funnel cake and churros - were stale. We figured this was because no one ever orders that stuff and didn't dock them any points for it.


 Overall, I was pretty impressed by Alborz. The prices aren't fantastic because their only real competition in San Francisco is the overpriced North Beach mainstay Maykadeh. But the food was great, service was attentive, and the atmosphere classy but relaxed. The additional light show provided by the sparks flying from the Van Ness muni made for extra entertainment during dinner.
author: Omid T.

description:
I prefer Alborz to Makyadeh anyday ! Hey, that rhymes!  
I find Alborz's food & service superior to Makyadeh's and prior to finding Alborz, I thought Makyadeh was the ONLY place to eat in the SF for Persian food.

Their palate is spot on:  the Fasanjoon was the best I've had outside of LA, although their Zerhesk Polo was a little less so.  Their ice cream seems homemade, and ditto all of their entrees.  My guests have all chosen Lamb and rave about it--not personally eating lamb, I cannot attest to it, but I can say it's beautifully presented.

Excellent short wine list to accompany the special dinner or lunch.  I suggest asking the server is you don't know about Persian salads, they are awesome!  Mostokiah, Shirazi and Torsi  are all excellent in my "LA Standards for Persian Food".

~Ms. Ali
author: A W.

description:
So tasty! My backup plan with my boyfriends mom doesn't cook authentic persian food for a while. I love love love the chicken kabob and the rice is taste too. Garlic yogurt is my fav espically when you mix some with your rice. 

They serve generous portions so I never have room for dessert but I can only imagine how amazing that would taste.  =) 


I bring all my friends here when I want to introduce them to persian cuisine. =)
author: Lisette E.

description: Being half Iranian, I can be a Persian food snob. The Koobideh is probably the best thing on the menu. As for the other kabobs, I often find them tough, and a bit over cooked. As well as the Khoresht Baademjaan being super overcooked, and tasting a bit burnt. I've given this place more than one chance, and have been unable to get one decent meal. I'd recommend any other Persian restaurant in San Francisco before this one.
author: Natasha S.

description:
Bomb az kabob and koobideh. There are only 2 places in the city that I know of that serve persian food so the coices are limited.

The staff is friendly and the food is great.

***Warning*** Do not eat koobideh for lunch. It is one of the best individual food items in the history of the world, but you will fall asleep if you eat koobideh for lunch :)
author: Isaac N.

description: Driving around and looking for a nice resaturant for kabab/chicken kabab  I told my friend let us go to this Persian restaurant I went there once and today will be my second try, and the second try was better than the first try the host/waitress was very friendly, very relaxing atmosphere, and  the food is great. they really have a very tasty chicken kabab with Sumac and baba ghanooj the Persian style Yummy!!.  I will go there next time I am craving chicken kabab.
author: Wafa R.

description:
Okay, so I'm sort of a Persian food snob, as I grew up eating it; but I'm not writing this review based solely on the food.  It's more about the horrible service and over-priced menu.  My husband and I were craving kabob and decided to go to Alborz.  We've been to Alborz a few times, especially when my parents are visiting and we generally have had a good experience--but not this time!

We got there and were seated away from all of the other customers (a plus), but right next to the doorway to the kitchen (a minus--we could hear the barked orders all night).  As we waited for our order to be taken, I noticed my glass was dirty (finger prints and dried on food smears), the plate was cracked and my knife looked like it had been wiped instead of washed.  Ge-ross! 

We finally gave our order--a plate of tah dig (crispy rice from the bottom of the rice cooker served with stew on top) and one sultani (steak and ground beef kabobs).  Now, in the past sharing these two dishes would fill both of us up, even if we hadn't eaten all day long.  To our disappointment, the plate of tah dig arrived looking like they had prepared them the world's tiniest pots!  Furthermore, the rice tasted OLD--I know this, b/c I sometimes recook left over rice on the stove to get tah dig, but it never tastes right.  This tah dig had to have been more than a day old.  On top of that, the same guy that was busing tables, was the guy that served our food!!! And the "serving fork" provided for the tah dig was placed on our table by holding the tine end!! WTF?!?!  I'm supposed to serve myself runny stew with a fork that you just molested with your dirty hands?????

Then the sultani came out--again, what happened to the large portions? I could eat the entire plate by myself!  I have to say the kabob was delicious, but after the night's earlier events, I was left to wonder if I was eating old food off a dirty plate.  

My poor husband was still hungry, so we decided to order desert--zulbeyah and bomeyeh (persian sweets).  Now usually this is a real treat, b/c I don't know how to make this stuff at home.  But when the desert came out and I took that first bite of zulbeyah, there was no "savoring the gooey yumminess"; instead I about spit out the OLD and STALE desert!  

The real disappointment came when we got the check--$60 BEFORE TIP!!! WTF?!  We ordered an appetizer and one meal with desert.  How the heck can this be a $60 meal???  We added up the items, and sure enough....$60.  SO NOT WORTH IT!  Especially after the horrible service, I was inclined to leave NO TIP; but alas, I thought of my embarrassed mother lecturing me about the struggles of "her people" trying to make it in America and I left a 20% tip.

At the end of the night, my husband and I waved good-bye politely as we left the restaurant, with a substantially lighter wallet and even lighter stomach.
author: S. L.

description: Delicious! First time at this restaurant and will definitely go back.  The aroma was like my grandmother's kitchen. (no I am not Persian, but Mediterranean).  I loved the combinations of all my favorite things: orange zest, pistachio, basmati, cinnamon.  I could not decide what to have, so I went for the spices in the entrees  instead.  By the way, will you people stop calling it "pita bread".  That flat bread is lavosh. (Heads up: they do not accept American Express).
author: Joan E.

description: Nice classy/comfortable atmosphere, plenty of food to share, good flavors, great iced tea, the pita was great to start.
author: Andrew K.

description:
I will admit that I would eat Persian food 6 nights a week if I could convince myself that I would not explode from the rice. I tend to save this for when I go home to visit the family and divulge in the flavors in San Francisco by 1. visiting Maykadeh or 2. slaving over my stove at home (yes, I actually spent 6 hours last week making Ta Chin, but it was so well worth it).

I decided to check out Alborz last weekend after reading some of the Yelp reviews (especially those of fellow Iranians) and I must say I was not that impressed. I must say that I did go here during Ramadan before it was dark out, but I think even that does not excuse the restaurants god awful staff. They were downright terrible. 

The Ghormeh Sabzi was made with beans that seemed a bit off kilter, but the Ta Dig, Fesenjan, and Koobideh were all delicious. The market next door is convenient and the portions are big enough to make two meals.
author: Alicia J.

description:
After returning from Alborz, I wanted to sit on my review for a few days to process to be fair.

Here are my thoughts:

Food:  Simple, elegant, fresh.  While flavorful, the kebabs and the appetizers were not elaborate.  The quality overall was good.  

Price:  My opinion is that the food was overpriced.  I feel that even though the quality was satisfactory, the price was not equivalent.
For a lunch consisting of two Kebab main dishes, two very simple appetizers (hummus & panner salad) and one soda we ended up paying approximately $37.00.  This did not include tip.

Service:  Very attentive and welcoming.
author: Hiromi N.

description:
SLEAZY!! We purchased a gift certificate for them through Restaurant.com - but they refused to honor claiming that they "didn't have a contract with them anymore and didn't have to honor it." The restaurant was almost completely empty and we were there for the first time - but they didn't care if we left... so we walked out. Contacting Restaurant.com revealed that they have never cancelled their gift certificates with them, so they apparently are just using those gift certificates to get people in the door. Didn't work with us. We will never go back again! 

NOTE: Only gave them 1 star because we couldn't give them zero.
author: Dan P.

description:
This place pretends to be fine dining (about $40 per person per dinner), but is actually below my expectations.

Food is tolerable, although meat for kebab comes in kinda flat pieces (which is okay for cheaper mediterranean restaurants).  Bread is a regular flat pita bread, not impressed.

Location is good.

Athmosphere is okay, but below my expectations for a fine Iranian place. It feels like they can change nothing in the interior design and make it Italian, or just anything.

+1 to "the workers were standing behind the bar, chit chatting" comment. There's no feel that they care. Again OK for a cheap place, not OK for expensive place. We had to come down to them to pay.

They added 18% tip automatically (we were just a group of 3).
I didn't ask why they did it, but I think this is ridiculous. Which gives them a well-deserved 1 star rating. Will not come back. If they didn't do the tip trick thing, I'd say it's about 2-2.5 stars.

I asked if they're the same chain with Alborz restaurants in other states. They said they're only affiliated with Alborz restaurants in California.

The price range is wrong. It's $40/pp with 3 people ordering: one shared appetizer, one meal for one, one "plate for two" and one beer each. If you choose the cheapest meal and no appetizer, you can make it $30, but it barely fits there. Overall, it's more a $$$ place rather a $$.

RE Elaine Y vs Sina O. review: it's a defensive review, criticizing Elaine's review, but also giving 4 stars without explaining why he gave 4 stars. I agree with Sina's comments about proper expectations for Persian food, but I don't think the food is the main issue there. Attitude is the issue. For some people it manifests as "bad food", for some people in other things, but if a place is screwed up, it's screwed up. I doubt you can get people to like it more by teaching them how to be more selective in what to order.
author: Dmitry K.

description:
Great kabobs....great stews.......
reasonable price.....
author: Kasra V.

description: The food is delicious and the atmosphere is conducive to intimate conversation.  The negative rating is due to the poor attitude and service we received in using a restaurant.com coupon.  The gist of the matter is that this restaurant does not like accepting restaurant.com coupons.  The hostess, on 3 instances during our initial visit, asked us if we were done ordering, so she could tally up the bill and see if we reached the $100 food minimum for use of the $50 coupon.  The over-inquiry made us feel rushed.   Before we even finished our meal, she even tried to say "well, why don't we just settle the bill and we'll just go ahead and deduct $25 from your total."  Our final food bill was just a hair over $100 and we were able to use the $50 coupon.  In this economy, yet again, why do consumers have to tolerate this CRAP from restaurants who are already desperate for business?
author: Lark A.

description:
Food was decent. We came at lunch on a Friday and questioned whether things had been reheated. Lavash was served cold, and we did not see any of the onion/feta that everyone else mentions. I don't know if they aren't as good as they were closer to when they opened or if they were "off" that day, but a good restaurant shouldn't have off days.

The meat quality is nice and the spice blends are done well but yes, something is missing. The food is presented in a very typical persian way, just some rice here in a heap and some meat there and there you go. Maybe if it was more artful they'd earn more stars from me. 

If this place wasn't trying to be fancy (since they replaced c'est la vie, a restaurant trying hard to be a 4 star french restaurant), I'd give them 4 stars, but sin ethe atmosphere suggests they're to have the whole package, I just can't give them four.

So yes, the food is good, but for the presentation, and some small details, compared to the pricing (since they are in competative berkeleY), I probably wouldn't go here again.
author: Caroline C.

description:
I've visited Alborz three times after stumbling upon it on accident.
The first time my boyfriend and I ate there, it was pretty good. (Not as good as his mom's cooking or the Persian food you can get in LA, though!). The second time...it was ok.

Thrid time...not so good. Plus the new staff (a non-Persian) was extremely rude. I don't think we will be eating here any more.

Either we will find a new Persian restaurant to eat, or we will just have to wait to go back home to LA to enjoy awesome Persian. Either that or I will learn how to make it myself. I already have the salade shirazi down. Piece of cake.
author: Britany L.

description:
When I need a taste of home I go to Alborz.  Great kabobs and kashk-e bademjan, good service without the pretentiousness.  I only give it four stars because I've never had a gorma sabzi better/as good as my mom's at any restaurant.

I used to go to Maykadeh when it was the only Persian place in town, but it's too overpriced and the service was kind of snotty.  I actually had one waitperson say to me "you're not 100 percent Persian, are you?"  yuk.
author: SaraMitra P.

description:
The Koobideh was mighty fine, a little less complex than I like, but for $12 it's the best in the bay area in my opinion. The staffed seemed a little stuffy and dismissive, but they could probably tell that I'm the type of person to start a review with a statement on quality-to-price.

I must say I like the staff and atmosphere at the location in Berkeley much more. The floor to ceiling window view of Van Ness Ave is less than fine dinning. Treat Alborz like a good little Persian restaurant and not a place to go out before prom and you'll be satisfied.
author: Matt C.

description:
Alborz has some of the better Persian food that I have tried. The kebabs were all delicious, especially the filet mignon kebab. The bread and Basmati rice are tasty, as was the sampler appetizer plate. The food wasn't amazing, but was very good if you're in need of some Persian food when in the area. The prices are a bit high for 'just good' food, which may keep me from eating here very often, but certainly isn't a reason to write Alborz off... It isn't a bad idea to try it at least once. 

My first visit to Alborz left me satisfied; I wouldn't mind coming here again.
author: Aaron J.

description:
