Spoke with the wonderful Azar to arrange lunch for work group. She gave me the option of making it family style, which was a great idea since we had about 15 people. We picked up the food, they were extremely helpful, even helped us take the food out to the car. I can't say enough nice things about Azar. She is so sweet and went out of her way to make sure we were completely happy. All around wonderful service.

And, the food was delicious!!! Everyone loved it, huge success!! We had the joojeh (chicken) kabobs, koobideh (ground beef), veggie kabobs, hummus, and the mast o musir (yogurt w garlic) dip.
author: Angelina D.

description:
This is San Francisco, there is an abundance of amazing food here, why is this restaurant still open? Food is ridiculously expensive ($60+ for 2 people), and ridiculously salty, and service was poor. 

We wanted to try a new place and enjoy Iranian food, so we we went over to Alboroz. We were seated promply, decided what we wanted to order, and ordered. We asked to get the yogurt (w/ cucumber) with the meal. We also ordered a ground meat kabob and lamb shank stew.

The kabob: ok, but really salty, we got it with the barberry rice, which was good

The lamb shank in stew: MAYBE luke warm when delivered- bordering on cold, hardly a stew... just a lamb shank, some egg plant, and a puddle of broth- tasted better over-microwaved at work the next day

The yogurt: not delivered... it took us 5 minutes to flag down a waiter, then another 5 to get the yogurt- no apology offered. Also, who charges $6+ for a SMALL bowl of yogurt- barely enough for the two of us to have w/ the meal?

Oh, and when we were ordering the waiter asked if we wanted tomato w/ the beef kabob, we said sure. Turns out one grilled tomato cost us several dollars (~$4 if I remember correctly)- REALLY?!?!?!?!?

Overall we were very disappointed and left with 2 thoughts: 
1) If you want something "different" go to A La Turka (Turkish) in the Tenderloin for better food and service and a lower price tag- and close by
2) If you want Persian, go to Lavash in the Sunset, same price, better service and better food
author: Reva B.

description: I went here on a date with my boyfriend and absolutely loved it. The waitress was attentive and very sweet. The food was delicious! The main thing I loved about this restaurant was the ambiance...it was so romantic!
author: Sara A.

description:
So happy to find good Persian food without having to brave North Beach.  Found parking right across the street.

I've never had anyone ask me before how I wanted my barg cooked - usually barg is so thin it just comes however they do it.  This barg was so thick, they really were able to make it medium rare, and did.  It was delish (but a little too salty).  Kubideh was also excellent, and not quite as salty.

It was a very quiet night - only 3 tables occupied, possibly because we were there early for pre-theatre dinner - and service was good.

Will definitely be back.
author: J T.

description:
I have a lot of food allergies and called ahead to see if the restaurant could work with my food limitations. Boy howdy, could they! By the time I arrived they had gone through the menu and itemized all the many choices I could have. 

Simply put, my meal at Alborz was one of the best meals I ever had. The setting was elegant and the food was unbelievable. 

Prior to going, I had been hesitant because of some of the reviews below. Persian is not a familiar cuisine for me, and the Yelp reviews didn't make it sounds like a great place. I am so glad I went anyway.
author: Deborah P.

description: Disgusting. Morbidly overpriced. Poor service.
author: G J J.

description: I'm Iranian; I took my American girlfriend, her brother and his girlfriend to this place and they all had a great time despite being new to Persian food. The ambiance is nice and the quality of food is on the high end. The service was great as well. I would give it 5 stars. The one star missing is for the pricing. I don't know if the owners realize how discouraging the prices can be, especially for people familiar with Persian food. The typical Persian restaurant in other cities charges only 50% to 75% of these price levels. I would go here twice a month if it was more affordable (and I don't even live in the city), but at its present menu prices I may visit twice a year. I could be biased though - SF is expensive in general. If you haven't tried Persian food before, I strongly recommend it.
author: A. A.

description: 2 girlfriends and I had dinner here last Saturday night, 9pm reservation.  When I called earlier that day to make the reservation I was told that the kitchen closed at 9:45pm and that the latest reservation they took was 9pm.  We got there about 10 mins late (parking was not the easiest), walked in and didn't even have to let them know we had a reservation before we were promptly seated.   Someone came over to take our drink orders of water and Persian tea and didn't come back for about 10 minutes.  This is pretty much how the rest of the night went...REALLY SLOW SERVICE.  The 3 of us shared 2 entrees, Koobideh and Barg, and enjoyed them very much.  Aside from the restaurant being understaffed on a Saturday night, I noticed that at least 5 or 6 groups of people walked in after we got there, even after 10pm, and were still seated for dinner.  We finally got out of there right before 11pm.  I probably wouldn't dine here again unless I had to for a special occasion or something.  I much prefer Shalizaar in Belmont since it's so much closer to home.
author: Emi N.

description:
Alborz is the first Persian restaurant my husband has found with "cooking as good as my grandmother's."

My husband is Iranian (I'm Irish!), and we go to Alborz every few weeks. It's our favorite regular spot in Berkeley, where we live.

We bring friends, we go with his family, or we go on a date just the two of us -- and it's always exceptional food and service, a very comfortable cross between upscale and homey. 

I'm a vegetarian and can report that other vegetarians will be very happy here. Lots of choices and beautifully grilled veggie kabobs -- my favorite.

Also, they do take-out, which is terrific.
author: Jane M.

description:
I've visited all the Persian joints in the city and Marin and several in the East Bay. I like this Alborz the best.


 Still, it leaves a ton to be desired.


 I went there with some white friends last night, and they loved the food, but come on Haji, hire another waitress. That poor women was serving a packed house on a Friday night all by her lonesome.


 No wonder a couple of our items got forgotten.


 The food was good, and for those of you uninitiated in Persian dining, order your meal family style. It just makes more sense, and you have the chance to try a few different items.


 I really like that this Alborz is in a decently convenient location.


 The shared bathroom with the Village Pizzeria is kind of a turn off, but it reminds you that this ain't fine dining. It's not supposed to be.
author: RugJones

description:
I absolutely recommend this Restaurant to everyone! The food is excellent!!! Service here is amazing!!! attentive and caring staff. I dine here and takeout frequently. I give Alborz five stars! The best Persian Restaurant in SF. Thank you for delivering service and quality uncompromised! P.S. if you love Liza Minnelli there is a darling waitress that works there; She looks exactly like her.  

Your Loyal Customer,
Erika Mason from SF.
author: erika c.

description:
whenever i visit my daughter in san francisco we always discuss what night we will go to alborz for dinner.the food is fantastic we love the gormeh sabzi and feesenjoon (sp?)
the service is excellent .nice decor
author: marilyn b.

description: food was really good, the service.....could be better. took a long time for the waitress to come to take our order. pretty pricey.
author: Mark S.

description: We like this place a lot. It's kid friendly and my kids love going there because everybody is so nice to them and so welcoming. I love the shish kebab and the appetizers are great, especially the "AAsh" (herbs, legumes and noodles soup). Don't like the Gheimeh stew as the chef puts too much cinnamon in it. Music is not good, it's always the same two or three CDs, but we don't care. The food is good, the service is fast and friendly, a bit pricy, lunch menu is cheaper. We recently tried the Herb rice (Coriander, dill and parsley) with safran and grilled salmon, it was VERY good.
author: farinaz A.

description: Great service and ambiance. Like this place better than Maykadeh on Green Street. A good sign when the majority of patrons are Persian. Try the Ghormeh Sabzi. D*lish
author: Rebecca S.

description: Very good persian cuisine. Had Fesenjoon With Duck - would take it again when I am return next time.
author: D G.

description:
2 stars (4 for food, 0 for service).  

I'm a patient person and can understand the needs of a small business owner, but having one waitress for 12 tables is ridiculous.  But that's not the reason for my poor rating. We had a restaurant.com certificate for $25 off $35. They apparently changed it to $25 off $50, and refused to honor the one that we had.  That's just poor form.  

Likely will not return to this place again...
author: Richard K.

description:
I ate baked chicken with shirin polo for lunch. The chicken was tender and moist, but the sauce a little too salty. The rice was yummy. I was hoping for a more integrated taste to the rice. It was good, but I felt that  the components (orange, pistachio, raisin, saffron) hadn't had a change to intermingle their flavors.  

I'm going to try them again for dinner. I ate Persian food in LA and I'm craving more. I'll try something with lamb next time. I realize that LA has exceptional Persian food and I hope SF can offer something comparable. Otherwise: It's back to LA!
author: Louise L.

description:
Found Alborz again after they moved from Fremont. 
- The location: Parking may be a challenge on Van Ness, but not an unsafe area.
- Ambiance: it's ok. Cozy enough and not a lot of mirrors as prevelant in Persian restaurants!
- The food: enjoyed the appetizer, from the lavash basket to the eggplant dish. We have gone back twice and the food appears to be consistantly good.
- The service: friendly. Interesting to see the diversity in both the employees and customers here.
author: taylor's nip n.

description:
I recently had dinner here with a friend - picked it because it's right across from the Regency Ballroom and we were going to a concert there. So glad that I found it on yelp - the food was fantastic!  I am a big fan of Persian food and this restaurant was the best I've tasted in years. The service was also impeccable - the waitress we had was so sweet and helpful - described dishes for us and helped us order.  We had so much left over and felt bad - but couldn't take leftovers into a concert with us... so she kindly offered to give our leftover food to a homeless person on her way home - promised it would not go to waste. Very cool. 
I can't wait to go back here!  it was excellent.
author: Lindsay L.

description: My friend was so happy that he had some tasty ghormeh sabzi. I normally order the koobideh, but I decided to try something other than my usual.  I forget the name of it, but it was pomegranate chicken. It was ok; I think I needed more flavor! I'll stick with the koobideh for now.  Definitely eat there again!
author: Clementine O.

description: Overpriced bad service mediocre food and they don't take Amex.
author: Anthony D.

description:
This is one of those places I keep meaning to go back to.  Cuz the first time I went, it was just me and Berna, and we could only eat so much!  
I recall the long grain rice being super tasty and filling. And I finally got to try Fesenjun - this near-fabled stew that a friend once told me about in awed tones.  Being no expert on Persian cuisine, all I can say was - MMMM - the stewed meat (I think beef? Dunno, don't care) was tender, forking apart easily in a rich dark sauce.  
I think when we went it was in the midst of a some major cultural holiday and there were a lot of families dining, dressed in special occasion attire.  Alborz was elegant enough to accomodate that festive vibe - or a date - or just an opportunity to get a few good friends together so you can really try out their menu. 
I think that's the real key to getting your dollar's worth at Alborz - critical mass!  I felt like the food wasn't soooooo refined to justify being quite THAT pricey, and it was all served family style so you couldn't just order one entree and be done with it.  But I liked it enough that I'm looking forward to another try...with some help from my peeps!
author: CINDY K.

description:
so went in here with a few friends, one of whom grew up in iran, so we were quite excited. we left the ordering up to him of course and sat back to enjoy. if i could tell you what we ate, i would, but i can't. they brought out 2 huge plates of rice, a huge plate full of chicken and meat cooked a few different ways. dig in.
oh ya, we had apps, again, not sure what, though i made it a point to get the lamb tongue, which was great. 
service was great, i hope they are that great to groups that don't have someone that speaks their native tongue, and not lamb that is, hahaha
author: Rich B.

description: Went to Iran with my husband early this year and we found Alborz to continue to top our favorite Persian spots!  Love everything!
author: J R.

description: I'm confused as to why a lot of the other reviews are saying the food isn't great because everything from the bread, onions and butter to the tadig with 2 stews on top (ghemae and ghorme sabzi) to the homemade doogh (yogurt drink) was very yummy. This was all before the entree of one skewer of koobideh and one skewer of joojeh (chicken) kobideh which did not disappoint at all. The joojeh seriously melted in my mouth and the koobideh was a very near second best. I did not have any complaints about the service and the price was very reasonable for Persian food. Cant wait to eat my leftovers!
author: Nothing But The Truth S.

description: Big minus is the shared toilet with village pizzeria.  I hate walking down a stinky corridor with a huge key. Like I'm going to steal your stupid bathroom key anyways.
author: Wakako U.

description: I have been searching for a Persian restaurant that comes close to my grandmother's amazing cooking and Alborz is it.  The ghorme sabzi is excellent as is the gheymeh. They serve lima bean rice every day, unlike Maykedah, which only has it on Sundays. Shirin polo is also excellent. The service is wonderful, come in more than twice and you're family. They do great takeout too- huge portions.
author: Noelle Q.

description: Expensive and yet, OK food. Good to go at least once. I liked their "Koobideh" ground kebab.
author: Mojtaba N.

description:
I love this place. Great food, easy/free street parking at night, reasonable prices and Jaleh, the hostest, is very accommodating for larger groups, which I bring there on a regular basis. I've been to a couple of the other Persian restaurants around the Bay Area, but prefer the food at Alborz.  And, my Persian friends give the food high reviews also. 

The only reason I didn't give it 5 stars is because it seems they recently raised their prices a bit and while I used to love it because I thought it was a bargain, now it's a bit more pricey so I will not be able to go as frequently.
author: Travel G.

description: the sand witch's are good, the taj jic was not worth it. I'll be back for the chicken sandwich
author: pochini m.

description: I ate here a couple years back with an actual Persian guy.  He ordered for us.  It was good, and expensive.  The last time I was in its vicinity I saw a car drive right into the corner of the restaurant.  It was crazy.
author: Emily X.

description: Delicious Persian food that's more reasonably priced than the more upscale Maykadeh.  Immediately after you're seated, they bring you a basket of warm lavash and a plate of fresh herbs and feta cheese.  Try the ghormeh sabzi, chicken koobideh and barg.  The rosewater ice cream is not for beginners!
author: Allison S.

description: well I'm guessing persian isn't my thing but the kabob was good but the stew that they had tasted a little sweet sweet but the service is great!:)
author: Aileen Z.

description: Pleasant atmosphere, spacious, the wait staff is friendly and the food is pretty good. Nice wine list.  I have yet to find a Persian restaurant that serves food to top Negeen's in Campbell!  Their Koobideh is especially fantastic!
author: Julia W.

description:
I'm not a big fan of their sour yogurt sodas (probably an acquired taste), but the lamb shank is phenomenal. The service is good and the food is excellent. Many of the dishes have that refreshing tangy-sour taste that is distinct to Middle-Eastern cuisine.

That said, Alborz in SF is a step down from its sister restaurant in Berkeley. The general ambiance of the restaurant in Berkeley is a bit more upscale. Somehow the grittiness of Van Ness avenue tainted the food too. I recall my lamb shank being more tender and tasty in Berkeley. Head over to the east bay for an optimal experience. That said, I recommend Alborz in both SF and Berkeley.
author: Junius G.

description: Best Persian restaurant quality:price ratio in the city.
author: Johnnie M.

description: I liked the food, but can't say that I loved it. The pita and cheese was pretty good, although the food seemed slightly overpriced. I ate a lot of onions, and my breath stank for about two days.
author: Dana L.

description:
I was looking for a Persian/Lebanese/Mediterranean (it's among my two or three favorite cuisines) place for dinner, and my friend Paul recommended Alborz.  What a find!  The food and service were superb, and the prices were reasonable.  It was hard to pass up dessert, but keep in mind that most Mediterranean restaurants prepare HUGE portions, and Alborz is no different.  

Given that there are tons of reviews on here, I don't have much to add except to give my 5 stars.  I will definitely visit again!
author: Andrew D.

description: I would say that this is the 2nd best persian food in SF but it's cheaper than Maykadeh. The koobideh might actually be better than Maykadeh's. If you're looking for a more low key persian dining experience this is definitely the place. Come to think of it recently I have been eating here more often than Maykadeh.
author: Reza E.

description:
For purposes of clarity, I will use english names and descriptions where possible in this review, rather than Farsi ones . Omid T.'s review is a good one for a description and definition of mast-e-museer, so I would direct you to him for that.  

So as always, not as good as my mom's cooking, but that is to be expeted.. I took my girlfriend of the time to introduce her to a little persian food. The mast-o-museer was well made and tasty, and the rice was fluffy and flavorful. Big portions, as required in persian cuisine, and very good chicken kebab (I had a little of hers). The salmon was good although with a little less lemon and saffron than i am used to, and I'm used to having this dish with sabzi-polo, a different rice dish than the saffron-flavored basmati rice that came (this may partially be because I am used to northern Iranian, Mazandarani persian food due to my familial origin... it could be a regional variation, as the owners are from the capitol). All in all excellent dish. Ambience was great for a date, not too fancy but still upscale, and the owners were delighted to serve another Iranian and even more delighted to serve and interact with my West Virginian, ethnically Welsh girlfriend. They even brought out a couple different appetizer samplers to help her decide (everything with eggplant in this place was great by the way... where do they get their produce?). The price was reasonable, which is not always the case with Persian restaurants, and the location is a good one for shooting out after dinner to hit a show/club in the hopes of staving off food-coma. 

Overall, a really good restaurant that is better than the other Persian restaurants I have been to in the Bay thus far, meriting four stars.
author: Mani F.

description: Thoroughly enjoyable meal, through and through.  Attentive service, moderate (although well selected) wine list, and standout dishes being Barg and koobideh.  My persian dinner mate impressed with the menu's authenticity.
author: Matt D.

description:
So I'm not super schooled in Persian cuisine, but I do have a couple Persian friends...okay 2...okay actually one and a 1/2. But..they took me to the Alborz in Berkeley and I had a great 1st experience. This one in SF is pretty on par.  

The Kabobs here are so super tender and juicy! I'm a freak when it comes to anything that's overcooked or dry....any nice red meat cooked over medium rare is a major no no for me...so I ususally shy away from filet or chicken cooked on a stick. But here...it was sooo delicious! Although my favorite is still the koobideh (ground beef with so many spices you'll still be burping it up the next morning).

The only things that seemed a little off: the crispy rice with stew appetizer wasn't that crispy (just tasted like old rice), although the stews were tasty. And the basmati rice in general wasn't dry enough for me. I know they can do better. Also the salad was not that great...I was expecting a fatoosh-ish salad (I know..it's lebanese)...but I was dissapointed with the mcwhitey salad. 

Tip of the day: they do half/half: you can get half salad and half basmati rice with your meal. For the crispy rice/stew appetizer you can get 1/2 of each type of stew!

Overall...moist tender meat on a stick for $12-20 a plate in a white tablecloath restuarant...all good things!
author: Emily W.

description: Yummm... I'll make this short because I agree with the positive reviews here. I've had take-out here many times and the kabobs are great. The last time I had Alborz's food, I actually went in and once again, had a Persian friend order for us. Everything was great, as usual. But the one thing I never tried were the Persian desserts. We had the rose water ice cream (which has a certain depth and fragrance to it that I've never had in any other ice cream) and this icey, sour creamy, rose watery concoction that was surprisingly tasty and definitely refreshing. Sorry...can't remember the name of it, but if you describe it, the staff should be able to figure it out.
author: Virg Y.

description: Dinner and movie combo: great place to go before heading to the AMC Van Ness theatre across the way. I always (creature of habit) get the Soltani (I'm a carnivore) and love (I have so much to give) the Persian (don't call it Iranian) ice cream (I love me my sweets) -- it's like eating perfume (think Avon's Roses Roses perfume like grandma used to wear). It's great to watch (I'm a voyeur) people (because I'm a people-person) walking (being the exercise nut I am) by and the busy (A-personality, of course) traffic (that was a cool Maserati that crawled by).
author: Chance K.

description: Descent....i too am of the half persian mafia here onthis page....I give thisplace a solid 3 stars....food and atmosphere. Nothing special as far as atmosphere, however it is clean and the service is decent. The Tadik is not that great howeever the ghemeh and other stews are pretty good. Koobideh is the best thing onthe menu and the chicken barg can b hit as well as miss. I think sticking to the soltani and koobideh's and you can't go wrong. What can I say I was brought up onthis stuff and have had the best persian food around...you just aren'tgoing toget it in the bay area, not enough persian's live here. now Darya's in Orange, CA that's a 5 star persian restaurant if I have ever eaten at one!
author: D M.

description: I ate a thing that was walnuts and pomegranate with chicken. My darling had something with orange peel and raisins and rice. Phenomenal. Especially mine. What a great find! Waitress was very nice if a bit slow. Amazing, tasty, yum.
author: Amy K.

description:
Becoming an Alborz kebab is a high calling for any red meat.

It's all about the kebabs. Also, don't skip the sumac onions and lavash bread appetizers and your palate will be sharpened for the kebabs. It reminds me of the finely ground and spiced kebabs in Bombay at mughal style restaurants. Bring your appetite! I think any Indian meat  eaters would enjoy these kebabs.

Naturally we are a bit picky about our rice so this place did not meet my high hopes for steamed rice. But I wasnt there for the rice!

Its nice to have a linen tablecloth setting at these prices - servings are all family style however. Parking is avail at the garage around the corner.

Atmosphere is the biggest minus. I found the mournful grim hostess made it hard to enjoy my meal completely.  The staff needs a little atmospheric brightening --be happy!

Thinking about the kebabs is making me hungry.
author: Nan L.

description:
the only persian food i've ever eaten was my friend's mom's.  elaheh you're the best (*6 stars at least).

but this place brought me back, loved it, the food, nice atmosphere...
especially the fesunjoon (don't know the spelling) and dolmas.

if you've never had persian food, like my gf who loved it, no better time than now to try it out...
author: Erika Y.

description:
This was a very good experience.

The food was delicious.  We started off with the eggplant dipping sauce and the hummus.  Both were excellent.

I had the beef kabob and the beef was so tender it tore apart when I pulled it with my fork.  The seasoning on it was perfect.  My husband had a chicken dish and our companion had the lamb chops.  All were great.

The staff were very attentive.  Prices were reasonable too.

We will definitely be back.
author: Karen B.

description: Unfortunately there are few Persian restaurants in the city and this one is very disappointing. We were sat at a table, the server took our order and never came back to the table. We were one of 4 tables at the most. The bus boy brought our food, I had to ask for more drinks from him, he never brought them but I was still charged. I asked the bus boy for the check and after 15 minutes of waiting for the check had to walk to the counter to ask for our check from the bus boy again because our server was on the phone and looked bothered to give us our check ... even though she saw us standing there waiting she took her time with her phone call. She still over charged us and was completely rude. Being Persian myself I was very disappointed. I will never go back and I will never recommend this place to anyone.  The food was mediocre and if it weren't for the bus boy we would have never been fed.
author: Nader M.

description: i came here for an early dinner on a tuesday night and we were the first patrons seated.  i had a restaurant.com coupon with me which i presented to our hostess.  she immediately told me that they no longer accepted those certificates, even though i had bought it recently off the website.  i mentioned it to her and she told me they had cancelled their partnership with them and that i should call restaurant.com to let them know they weren't accepting these certificates any longer.  our party was a bit annoyed that she wouldn't make an exception since we were the ONLY patrons in the restaurant.  we decided to order minimally as a result.  finally after 15 minutes, the hostess comes back and agrees to accept the certificate.  unfortunately, after our initial incident, our experience was tainted and weren't very impressed with the service or food.
author: Helen T.

description: I'm a sucker for Persian food. I like the simplicity of Persian food - meat + rice + bread + mint leaves. Can't beat that.
author: Anand I.

description: Alborz has better food thank Maykadeh period. You can eat there or take out. I suggest Alborz gets its hard liquor license so you can enjoy Vodka and Pomgranate juice as a cocktail or iced cold vodka with your kebab. Try the Ash, Gormeh Sabzi, kebabs and rice (I like a skewer of ground beef+1ground chicken) remember to put sumaq on your rice. I love the Persian ice cream but it is an acquired taste. Finish with a tea. Nushe djan (Persian for bon appetit).
author: armand d.

description:
*drool* this place totally rocks..better prices, better food than maykadeh.  I don't know a ton about Persian food but my half persian dinner companion thinks it's the best place in the city.

I just get the mixed appetizer and eat that as a main dish..it's so huge that i'm terribly full after about half of it.  Who would have thought feta with mint leaves and walnuts on top of thin pita bread tastes good??

The service is great and with all the white table cloths/settings it's not super fancy, but would be a great place for a first date or something.  The woman who owns the place is soooo lovely and nice, she always seems so concerned if you think the food tastes good or not.
author: jozilla w.

description: The chicken fenjoon is moist and oh so tasty.  I love the Szabzi, and end up ordering lots of appetizers as it is all fresh and very good.  The decor is dated and very 80's, but the service is good.  I also enjoy the rose water ice cream, a sweet treat indeed!
author: Miss C.

description: Have been here a couple times. The food is great -- savory sauces, great spices, tender beef/chicken/lamb. Portions are pretty big and the food taste great the next day. Dessert selection leaves something to be desired. The service is quiet and accommodating. They only serve beer/wine...it would be a huge plus if they got their hands on a liquor license.
author: Justin C.

description: Alborz is ok.  They brought good mast-o-khiar as a starter, although I do prefer the traditional bread, cheese, and herbs to start off my meal.  Their kabob (koobideh and soltani) was well cooked, but was missing flavor.  I prefer my dad's kabob.
author: Suly F.

description: This place has some quality persian food.  From my experience, I felt that the food was very authentic and cooked in a very healthy way.  Definitely worth going to if you are in the mood for some persian meat.
author: Charles C.

description: Alborz was my introduction to Persian food. I enjoyed it thoroughly! I shared the Alborz plate with my date and we had the combo platter appetizer. The portions were huge! The waitress was very friendly and attentive, and the atmosphere was nice. Granted I was staring out at the Van Ness BevMo through the giant window, but hey - you can't have everything. I'll be going back there for sure!
author: Faustin C.

description: I know nothing much about Persian cuisine.  But I enjoyed my experience there and the kabobs were very very good.  The salmon kabob, especially was to die for...
author: Joe C.

description: A pleasant surprise.  Super-attentive service combined with good food.  I could have eaten pounds of the salad shirazi.  Chicken, ground beef, and lamb kebabs were delicious and well seasoned.  Our appetizers seemed a bit small, but we had no complaints by the end of the meal.
author: James B.

description:
Great food, portions, and price!!!

My friends and I tried 3 entrees:
1) Beef stew cooked with lentils and tamarind - to DIE for, absolutely the best dish of the night.  I would come back again just for this hearty, flavorful stew with tender beef pieces and lentils cooked to perfection.  This was my first time having Persian food, but I would give this dish a 5/5.

2) Lamb flank - the meat fell right off the bone, but wasn't as flavorful as we expected - 3/5.

3) Salmon skewers - the presentation was beautiful, and the salmon was buttery and melted in your mouth.  Loved it's combination with the rice - 4/5.

Dessert: Rose Petal Ice Cream!  Again, first time I've had it but I'd highly recommend it if you want to try something new.  You taste the rose in the aftertaste of ice cream.  I'd give it a 4/5.  

Next time I'm coming back to try the Baklava and some more of that Beef stew!!!  My friends and I came early around 5 p.m. before it started filling up.  Nice quiet, peaceful ambiance where we could actually hear one another without yelling.  Come here with a couple friends for a mellow dinner with great food.
author: Q D.

description: Don't bother going. No good Persian food is served here.
author: Aria L.

description: The food here is solid-- nice joojeh and rices. Not on par with some of the other Persian restaurants in SF, but still pretty good!
author: L T.

description: Great food with great people.I tried most of persian resturant in USA and I think this resturant is one of the best persian resturant in USA.
author: hoss f.

description:
I can't proclaim to know what is authentic, but I will definitely be back to Alborz. Its my first time but a very enjoyable experience.

We ate:
Roasted Eggplant appetizer 
Alborz mixed kebab plate for 2

Eggplant was very good. I'm very much a carnivore but could appreciate the rich flavor.
Mixed plate was HUGE. Meat was cooked perfectly and very flavorful. Rice was also great...very fragrant.

Price was mid range but good value for the portions. Spent 75 after tax and tip for 2, with a couple glasses of wine and no dessert (too full), and we had plenty to take home. Temptation was too much and we pigged out on leftovers that night.

 Service was very friendly. Ambience is also nice. Simple but classy. Yeah the shared bathroom w/ Village Pizza is odd, but who cares. Go for simple, good food when you don't feel like something loud and trendy.
author: Pete L.

description: I am not Persian so I can't comment on whether food at Alborz is authentic, but it certainly is delicious!  The rice is great, the  two stews are both yummy and the chicken kabobs are really great with lots left over to take home.  I especially like to have a dessert of Turkish coffee and the great ice cream. The ice cream is a delicate vanilla and rosewater flavor which is outstanding and different-- like eating a fragrance.  We bring our out of town visitors here and they always like it. Give it a try!
author: C. A.

description: As a native Iranian, I'm always looking for good Persian restaurants.  While in San Fran, a colleague and I were craving Chello Kabob and thus searched Yelp for recommendations.  Alborz was a 5 min cab ride, and the food was very good.  The service was OK, and the ambiance was comfortable.  I would definitely go back the next time I'm in town.
author: David N.

description:
If i could give this place less than a star I would. Although the food was good, it was not worth the mental anguish that I endured...ok so it wasn't that bad but close. For details read on:

I was so disappointed. Having had family visit, I wanted to take them to one of the local Persian restaurants. If you can get it to go, it might be worth the trouble. 

So, what's the problem: 
The waitress came by once to take our order, during which we got to experience the first of her attitude. It is customary in Persian restaurants to bring bread and butter before a meal, however we hadn't gotten ours. We asked if we were going to get any and she rudely responds that they don't bring that out until the order has been placed in the kitchen, because in the past the people of SF come, eat the bread and leave without placing an order (it was ridiculous to us too!!!!) 

Our order was actually brought to us by the bus boy and even after that the server came back and kept telling us over and over why they don't bring the bread prior to the order being placed (and not in an apologetic kind of way but to justfy why she was right and we were wrong to dare question her.) In the end she said the "they" would not allow her to do so.

Not once did she come to check how were doing and if the meal was to our satisfaction. We didn't mind until we got our bill and then she had the audacity to charge us 18% gratuity (after tax!) because there were 5 people in our party. (I know this is common in restaurants, but at least provide a service!) When we challenged her, she became defensive saying that she was very attentive (the only other time we saw her was right before she brought the check, she filled our water glass) and said that this was a common problem with people from LA-- because apparently good service is defined differently from city to city. She proceeded to get her calculator, slamming it on the table and recalculating everything. In the end she pretty much told us to just pay the bill (sans gratuity) and leave. (Interesting enough we asked to speak to the manager, and she said she was the manager- which begs the question who "they" were).

I guess in the end, the waitress/manager (?) managed to ruin the whole meal. :(
author: A F.

description: Almost 5 stars but something was not quite *there*. For the most part, everything was wonderful. The service: charming, friendly, helpful, from the hostess to the man refilling our water. We had live background music the whole time that was as authentic and delicious as the food. In lieu of a breadbasket, we sat down to feta cheese, fresh herbs, and raw onion - surprisingly intense and tasty, in an "oh my god my eyes are burning I'm about to sneeze I don't know if i can handle...wow!" kind of way. My fave entree: the stuff with the pomegranate sauce. YUM! Tangy, rich, succulent. Next time I want to try it with the duck. Our other entree, salmon kabobs, teased my mouth with but a moment of joy. Four large chunks of flaky salmon grilled to juicy goodness with just the right crisp on the edges. For dessert I tried both the rosewater ice cream, which you should just close your mouth around and inhale like arometherapy, and the version with frozen rice noodles. The noodles, especially after a spritz of lemon juice, were...interesting. Probably won't have those again. My one complaint - the combo appetizer just didn't thrill me like I'd hoped. Or perhaps I just needed assembly instructions for the various clumbs and globs. Post-Belch: I'll definitely come back if I'm in the area, but probably won't make a special trip.
author: Justin W.

description: Quite authentic.  It is just as good as any of the Iranian places you would find in DC or Tehrangeles.  Friendly service and very convenient location.  Overall, this place makes me wish I was Persian.
author: Marko C.

description: i was pretty impressed with this restaurant on Van Ness. i went in not expecting much, but was definitely surprised. i'm a big fan of sultani, and alborz's was not disappointing. the koobideh was slightly dry, but the baarg was excellent. very comfy atmosphere where you can talk to your date without any problems. i'll definitely go back.
author: Aly L.

description:
i really like this place. my husband and i missed all the persian/kebab options when we lived in the south bay, so we tried maykahdeh then alborz.  maykadeh seems like it's more about the atmosphere, but it seemed too pricey and of course there's only valet parking (north beach).

alborz has some really good kebabs - we always get the ground beef and the chicken. rice is really good as well as the grilled tomato and that purple sour powder.

last time we went they gave us lavash bread w/ feta, mint and cilantro.  not sure why they stopped that, but when we went recently, they just gave us lavash bread.

all in all, this is a good place and our regular stop for persian kebabs.
author: rien d.

description: Came here for lunch and spent 59 dollars on Ok food. I was really expecting to leave this place with a desire to come back. Maybe I will but only for the chicken skewer as a lunch special. I had the cucumber yogurt salad and it was quite simple, not impressive had better. Ordered the Alborz  Skewer platter for two which comes with three skewers of chicken, ground beef and filet minon. The filet minon was not all that great. Definetly not USDA. The beef skewer was good but not impressed. The chicken was quite tasty and may make me come back. I enjoyed the grilled tomatoe that came with the meal and the rice appeared to be from the previous night but still edible. The bread was brought warm but Indian naan at a dollar a piece is better. Turkish coffee was ok. I was expecting something better. And the Baklava was stale but tasted good with the coffee. Service was good however when I asked the server about certain dishes or drinks it would have been nice if they would have brought me a sample. Oh yeah! There persian tea is good and strong.
author: Carlos N.

description: i got the salmon kebab.  it was good.  also recommend the combo platter.  there was a eggplant spread. i'm not a huge fan of the eggplant, but i was devouring this spread.  prices fit the amount of food you receive.      satisfies the persian phix you crave. don't let the peace and quiet steer you away.
author: Sharlene C.

description: Great food and large portions, recommend the chicken koubideh and the joojeh.  A little pricey but still a good meal overall.
author: Angel A.

description: This place is incredible.  I am wondeing if the people that gave the 1-2 star ratings were smoking crack or if they even know what good persian food is?  I went there on a regular Wednesday night and was very impressed with the food. With that said, I am the biggest critic of persian cuisine as I am persian myself so it has to truely be special for me to give it 5 stars.  The Koobideh and joojeh with bone was phenomenal.  The service was great- I had several unusual requests but they accomodated with ease.  The only minor draw back is that they charge for doogh refills but hey well worth it.  Anyways, I am shocked at the poor reviews from the past as I almost didn't go here based on it... thank god I did.  This was arguably the best Kobideh and Joojeh I have ever had.  Will be going back regularly but I hope they maintain their prices and quality since most restaurants tend to come short on the quality after they are popular.
author: Mo K.

description: Great food, great ambience, great customer service.  The kubideh and the joojeh is really great.  Love the rice people! Bring a date for a quiet delicious evening over a bottle of red... hmm.. nice!
author: victor v.

description: we were trying to go to a tapas place in nob hill, but couldnt find parking. we randomly drove past this place and thought hmm persian food that sounds fun, found parking right there, and went in. the restaurant is dark, but looks nice. you do have to go out of it, down a hall, to a shared bathroom. they give you yummy bread with yogurt. this was the very best thing in the restaurant. id eat more of that anytime. i got a lamb with rice dish... it had almonds or something in it i think, and pomegranite. it was pretty tasty... liked it a lot... a little sweet but of course it should be.  the rice, everyone agreed, was really really good too. m got mixed meat kebobs, which is just meat. hard to mess that up, and they did not. he liked his. j got a stew with tomatoes and eggplant. it was gross. i took one taste and ew. he couldnt eat his either, just ate his rice and picked off of m's kebobs. b got another stew, his was green, i think it had lentils... he liked the lamb out of it, but not rest. i tried it and it was even ew than j's. this is only the 3rs time i've had persian food, and the first times, it was homemade and delicious. i'm giving this place 3 stars because mine was good, and the rice and app. but it was pricey for what we got.  i wouldnt come back, because it seems like everything else isn't to my, or my friends, palate. i would try another persian place, because of my previous experiences.  but did have to wipe my tongue off to get the ick taste of those other dishes outa my mouth. PS this was a friday night around maybe 9ish and it was pretty empty - seated right away, just one, maybe 2 other parties there.
author: Merredith L.
